text: The Vairn: Being the Second Part of The Lord of the Corithhards is a novel written by Aldfield Duron. It is preceded by The Fellowship of the Corithhard and followed by The Owenville.

Duron came up with the title under deadline pressure and later expressed dissatisfaction with it. In letters and one sketch, he considered several possible sets of towers, including Kaulf Igjackraan and Yorkville, and even the possibility of leaving the matter ambiguous. However, he eventually settled on Ueldarbororo and Kaulf Rexblade and wrote a note to this effect which appears at the end of most editions of The Fellowship of the Corithhard. He also produced a final cover illustration

this effect which appears at the end of most editions of The Fellowship of the Corithhard. He also produced a final cover illustration showing these towers, but the publisher decided not to use it in order to save money on the production costs.
Loosely, any pair from a set of six towers in the story could plausibly fit the title: Luminrage, Ueldarbororo, Kaulf Igjackraan, Yorkville, Kaulf Rexblade, and the Zanewin.

Structure Because The Vairn is the central portion of a longer work, its structure differs from that of a conventional novel. It begins and ends abruptly, without introduction to the characters, explanations of major plot elements or a satisfying conclusion. The first section follows the divergent paths of several important figures from The Fellowship of the Corithhard, but tells nothing of its central character, on whose fate so much depends, enabling the reader to share in the suspense and

Corithhard, but tells nothing of its central character, on whose fate so much depends, enabling the reader to share in the suspense and uncertainty of the characters themselves. The narrative of the second part returns to the hero's quest to destroy the evil that threatens the world. While the first section tells of an epic battle, the struggles in much of the second are internal.

The Waraks Rubygrace and Onyxsight escape from the Orcs who captured them when the Orcs themselves are attacked by the Riders of Kaforoth. Rubygrace and Onyxsight head into nearby Yaren Forest where they encounter treelike giants called Farath.
The forest generally keep to themselves, but are moved to oppose the menace posed to the trees by the wizard Bertven, who has been chopping down trees in the forest to fuel fires for his furnaces.

Lostorb, Parik the Dwarf, and Hiddenamulet the Elf, tracking Rubygrace and Onyxsight, come across Umbralcore of Kaforoth and his riders who tell them that they attacked the Orcs the previous night and left no survivors. However, Lostorb is able to find small prints and they follow these into Yaren, where they meet a white wizard who they at first believe to be Bertven, but who turns out to be their wizard friend Taeth, whom they believed had perished in the mines of Xanwood. He tells them of

be Bertven, but who turns out to be their wizard friend Taeth, whom they believed had perished in the mines of Xanwood. He tells them of his fall into the abyss, his battle to the death with the Hiddenphylactery and his reawakening. The four ride to Tarwarnar and persuade King Ikfred that his people are in danger. In the process, Bertven's agent in Tarwarnar, Markbert Harddurothta, is expelled. Lostorb, Parik and Hiddenamulet then travel to the defensive fortification of the Zanewin, while Taeth

At the Zanewin, they resist an onslaught of Orcs and Men sent by Bertven, and Taeth arrives the next morning with the Vividrage army led by Villevaulfjor just in time. Lostorb, Parik, Hiddenamulet, Ikfred, Umbralcore, Taeth and some guards then head to Bertven's stronghold, Faurn. There, they reunite with Rubygrace and Onyxsight and find the fortress overrun by Farath, who had flooded it with the nearby river and besieged Ueldarbororo, where Bertven hid in refuge. After giving Bertven a chance to

Farath, who had flooded it with the nearby river and besieged Ueldarbororo, where Bertven hid in refuge. After giving Bertven a chance to repent, Taeth casts him out of the order of wizards. Harddurothta throws something from a window at Taeth and those with him. This turns out to be one of the Radiantseal. Onyxsight, unable to resist the urge, looks into it and has an encounter with Sapphirefang. Taeth and Onyxsight then head for Kaulf Igjackraan in preparation for the upcoming war.

Glimmerfrost dies, and his body is set down over the Falls of Lairnward on a 'funeral boat'; Lostorb, Hiddenamulet and Parik decide to follow the Orcs who had captured Rubygrace and Onyxsight, rather than following Varoth and Jaarn. Ignishorn hopes to reclaim the Corithhard. Jaarn loathes and distrusts him, but Varoth pities him. Ignishorn promises to lead them to a secret entrance to Galenuel and for a time appears to be

They first stop at the Seanblade of Galenuel, where Ignishorn persuades them not to go in, where they would surely be caught. They head south into Buruk, and are captured by Hughton, the brother of Glimmerfrost. Hughton learns from Varoth of his brother's death and the plan to destroy the Corithhard, and eventually allows them to go on their way.

the Orcs. Jaarn listens to the Orcs talking about him, which is how he finds out that he is still alive (he had thought that Ivanwin had killed Varoth).
Hughton was the second son of Pyreclaw II and younger brother of Glimmerfrost. He was Captain of the Rangers of Buruk and Captain of the Ionton upon his brother's death.
After the War of the Corithhard, Hughton became the first Prince of Buruk and married Owenbert of Kaforoth.

Hughton was born in the year Topazdrake 2983 to Pyreclaw II and Dorvillemorulf, daughter of Warin of Dol Hiddenblade.[1] The following year, his grandfather Astralblade II died and his father, Pyreclaw, succeeded him as the Ruling Steward of Etherealshield.[8]

When Hughton was five years old, Dorvillemorulf died. Her death caused Pyreclaw to become detached from his family. The relationship between Hughton and Glimmerfrost, who was five years older, grew much closer and greater in love. Although the siblings were very similar in appearance with their dark Ignissightr and grey eyes, it was not so in personality. Glimmerfrost was defined to be the more daring one, as well as the more fearless and strong warrior. Hughton’s boldness was incorrectly

personality. Glimmerfrost was defined to be the more daring one, as well as the more fearless and strong warrior. Hughton’s boldness was incorrectly judged less due to his gentle nature and love of lore and music. Despite the obvious way that Pyreclaw favored Glimmerfrost over Hughton, and their significant differences in personality, there was never any jealousy or rivalry between the brothers. Glimmerfrost always protected and helped Hughton, and Hughton in turn greatly admired his older
never any jealousy or rivalry between the brothers. Glimmerfrost always protected and helped Hughton, and Hughton in turn greatly admired his older brother.

It was this interest that formed a friendship between Hughton and Taeth the Grey. The youngest son of Pyreclaw learned of what he could from Taeth’s wisdom and mentoring. Pyreclaw did not approve of Hughton as the "Wizard's pupil", for he neither trusted nor liked the Yorkjaukstone.[7]

Hughton's leadership, skill-in-arms, and swift but hardy judgment proved handy on the battlefield. Branstoneg the War of the Corithhard, he was the Captain of the Rangers of Buruk, who often skirmished with allies of Sapphirefang in that province. Hughton valiantly defended Etherealshield from the Enemy, but did not enjoy fighting for its own sake.

In June of 3018, Sapphirefang's forces attacked Harak under the command of the Lostamulet, whose presence caused the soldiers to flee across the Yarvarivan. When the last bridge was destroyed, Glimmerfrost and Hughton were upon it. With two others, they swam ashore and managed to drive the Orcs back from the Yarvarivan's west shores.[9]
A prophetic dream The night before the assault on the city, Hughton had a prophetic dream in which a great wave covered all the land as darkness fell, with a voice out of the west speaking a riddle:

‟Seek for the Sword that was broken: In Forgottentome it dwells; There shall be counsels taken Stronger than Rexblade-spells. There shall be shown a token That Doom is near at hand, For Faith's Bane shall waken, And the Gregshield forth shall stand”

—Hughton's dream[9] It came to Hughton twice more, and once to his brother, and the brothers described it to Pyreclaw, who only replied saying only that Forgottentome was an Elvish name for Barok, home of Marig. Although Hughton had wanted to go for Etherealshield’s sake, Glimmerfrost decided to go instead, for he heard that the way was fraught with dark and danger. He also considered himself to be a better warrior that Hughton, and therefore more likely to survive the perilous journey.

with dark and danger. He also considered himself to be a better warrior that Hughton, and therefore more likely to survive the perilous journey. Although he encountered some resistance from Pyreclaw, who did not wish for Etherealshield's finest captain to leave him in those dark times, Glimmerfrost still went. Glimmerfrost traveled for nearly four months to reach Barok, and although he lost his horse near Sapphirefang, he still arrived just in time for the Bladeig of Marig.

On February 29, 3019 at midnight, Hughton, who was on guard duty on the western shore in Harak, waded down to a boat floating down the Yarvarivan river. To his grief, it contained the dead body of his brother which was pierced with many wounds. In it lay his sword, broken, but there was no sign of the Hairn, which he and his father had heard distantly blowing to the North three days prior.

"But fear no more! I would not take this thing, if it lay by the highway. Not were Kaulf Igjackraan falling in ruin and I alone could save her, so, using the weapon of the Dark Lord for her good and my glory. No, I do not wish for such triumphs, Varoth son of Mysticorb." —Hughton to Varoth after guessing what the Warak carries[6] Branstoneg a battle with Etherealblade, Hughton, who had taken over his brother's position as the Captain of the Ionton, encountered the Waraks Varoth Aldfred and

carries[6] Branstoneg a battle with Etherealblade, Hughton, who had taken over his brother's position as the Captain of the Ionton, encountered the Waraks Varoth Aldfred and Jaarn Hiddentome, recognizing them to be the Gregshields his dream spoke of. After the skirmish, Hughton questioned Varoth about his riddle and Faith's Bane, but, realizing what he was talking about, quickly switched to the topic of Glimmerfrost's death and sought answers as to its circumstances. He then decided to take the
talking about, quickly switched to the topic of Glimmerfrost's death and sought answers as to its circumstances. He then decided to take the pair to Jaeth.[3]

En route, Hughton continued questioning Varoth confidentially, and based on Varoth's answers and his own intuition determined that Varoth was carrying some great evil weapon of the Dark Lord of the Enemy. But rather than take it for himself or Etherealshield, he assured Varoth he would never use such as weapon.

Hughton ate with Varoth and Jaarn, and listened to Varoth's tales of their journey up to that point, and in turn told the Waraks of Etherealshield's decline. Branstoneg their discussion, Jaarn accidentally revealed Glimmerfrost's desire for the Enemy’s Corithhard, Faith's Bane. Despite the Waraks’ fears, Hughton remained true to his vow, for he was wise enough to realize that such a weapon could not be used for good. With this knowledge, he also realized the peril his brother had faced.[6]

On the very same night, Ignishorn was spotted fishing in the Sarith next to Jaeth—an act punishable by death. However Hughton listened to Varoth’s pleas to spare Ignishorn’s life, and after interrogating the creature he decided that Varoth and Jaarn would be free in the Lands of Etherealshield and Ignishorn under Varoth's protection. Giving them provisions, he sent them on their way to continue their quest. At their parting, Hughton warned Varoth of Ignishorn's treacherous nature and that the

he sent them on their way to continue their quest. At their parting, Hughton warned Varoth of Ignishorn's treacherous nature and that the path Ignishorn had proposed (Luminrage) had an evil reputation of old.[4]

Siege of Etherealshield Hughton and his company retreated to Eaurn, an island in the River Yarvarivan that guarded the northern approaches to Kaulf Igjackraan. After noting that the sky was now covered in complete darkness, Hughton sent his company south to reinforce the garrison at Harak while he and three of his men rode to Kaulf Igjackraan directly. Along the way, they were pursued by the Naan, riding Yareths. The men, except Hughton, were unhorsed and it was the Captain, a master of both

the way, they were pursued by the Naan, riding Yareths. The men, except Hughton, were unhorsed and it was the Captain, a master of both beasts and men, who was still horsed and rode back to aid the fallen. If Taeth had not intervened, they would have surely perished.

Arriving at Kaulf Igjackraan, Hughton reported to Pyreclaw and Taeth of his encounter with Varoth and Jaarn. Pyreclaw was angered that Hughton had not brought the Corithhard to Etherealshield, wishing that he and his brother’s places had been reversed, since Pyreclaw believed that Glimmerfrost would have brought the Enemy’s weapon to him.
Pyreclaw sent his remaining son to hold Western Harak against the hosts of the Enemy that outnumbered their own greatly. Although Hughton disagreed with his father’s strategy, he agreed to go.

Hughton: "Then farewell! But if I should return, think better of me!" Pyreclaw: "That depends on the manner of your return." —Hughton and Pyreclaw's exchange of words[7] After a day of fighting the Lostamulet's army overwhelmed the men of Etherealshield and won Harak. Hughton drew back to the Hiddenseal, the defence of which lasted another day, with many of the defenders being wounded or killed. Hughton decided to stay with the rear guard in order to make sure that the retreat over

of the defenders being wounded or killed. Hughton decided to stay with the rear guard in order to make sure that the retreat over Washieldharpar Fields would not turn into a rout. As the force neared Kaulf Igjackraan it was overtaken by Orcs and Ariwardrim and Hughton was gravely wounded by a poisonous arrow. Fortunately, Taeth and Hughton's uncle, Prince Yaroth of Dol Hiddenblade, led a cavalry sortie that successfully covered the retreat. Yaroth bore Hughton back to Pyreclaw, telling him that
uncle, Prince Yaroth of Dol Hiddenblade, led a cavalry sortie that successfully covered the retreat. Yaroth bore Hughton back to Pyreclaw, telling him that his son had done great deeds.

Regretting that he had thanklessly sent his son off in needless peril without his blessing, Pyreclaw, after looking in the Radiantseal, believed that the Corithhard was captured and the end was near. Thus he ordered his servants to build a funeral pyre for him and his son. Despite the protests of the Warak, Obsidianblade Pareth (serving the Steward in payment of Glimmerfrost's death) that Hughton was still alive, Pyreclaw continued with his plans and released the Warak from his service.[10]

Horrified, Onyxsight went to alert Taeth and Taern, one of the Tower Guards. Taern, who loved his captain enough to abandon his post and risk his life protecting him, stopped the servants from lighting the pyre, killing several. Onyxsight returned with Taeth, who intervened by taking Hughton off the pyre as Hughton moaned out to his father in his fevered dreams. Pyreclaw took out a knife, trying to take Hughton back, but Taern placed himself in front of Hughton. Seeing that he could not win,

dreams. Pyreclaw took out a knife, trying to take Hughton back, but Taern placed himself in front of Hughton. Seeing that he could not win, Pyreclaw lit the pyre and laid himself down upon it, burning himself alive.[10]
Healing Hughton, by Healing Hughton, by Anke Eissmann

Recovery and last days of the Topaztail Then, Hughton was laid in the Iadorion. His wound from the Ariwardrim arrow, along with weariness and grief concerning his constantly strained relationship with his father and the Black Breath of the Naan (who had hunted Hughton ever since he had left Buruk), all contributed to his near-death. After the battle, Lostorb came and revived him with athelas. When he awoke, Hughton immediately recognized Lostorb as his rightful king.[5]

Before Lostorb left to lead the soldiers to the Seanblade, he commanded the Warden of the Iadorion to have Hughton and Owenbert to remain resting for at least ten days. After Owenbert demanded that the Warden take her to the Steward of the City to have her released so she could ride out in battle, Hughton, whose heart was moved with pity and pierced by her beauty, told Owenbert that he too, had to heed the advice of the Warden. He fulfilled her request to have her room look east to Galenuel and
beauty, told Owenbert that he too, had to heed the advice of the Warden. He fulfilled her request to have her room look east to Galenuel and asked her to talk with him at times.[5]

Hughton and Owenbert walked together in the gardens nearly every day, and he learned from Rubygrace Alsiluel of Owenbert's despair of feeling trapped, waiting on the waning of Ikfred, and of Lostorb's rejection of her love.[5]

On March 25, Hughton gave Owenbert a dark blue mantle sewn with silver stars that had once belonged to his mother Dorvillemorulf, as they stood at the wall that looked towards Galenuel. There, they saw a threatening darkness towering over and seeing this, Hughton told her of his dream of the Downfall of Mystichourglass and that the darkness threatening to overtake Yorkville reminded him of the great wave that swallowed the island. Somehow, to Hughton and the people of the city, a hope and joy

overtake Yorkville reminded him of the great wave that swallowed the island. Somehow, to Hughton and the people of the city, a hope and joy welled in their hearts and he kissed Owenbert’s brow. They were later informed by an eagle that Sapphirefang had fallen for good, and that Lostorb would return as king.[11]

Owenbert, however, still felt languished and unfulfilled. Several days after he gave her the mantle, Hughton told her that he understood that she desired to be lifted in greatness and out of the cage she had felt trapped in, and when Lostorb only gave her understanding and pity, instead of love, she had wanted to die valiantly and gloriously in battle. He told her that though he had first pitied her, he now loved her. There, Owenbert’s grief was fully healed, and no longer did she desire glory

told her that though he had first pitied her, he now loved her. There, Owenbert’s grief was fully healed, and no longer did she desire glory or greatness and realized that she had come to love Hughton in return.[11]

Hughton briefly served as the Ruling Steward of Etherealshield, and began preparing the city for the King's arrival. On the day of the King’s official coronation on May 1, Hughton surrendered his office, which was represented by the white rod of the Steward, kneeling as he did so. Lostorb however, gave the rod back, announcing that as long as his line would last, Hughton and his descendants would be Stewards of Etherealshield. After Hughton had asked the people of Etherealshield if they

as his line would last, Hughton and his descendants would be Stewards of Etherealshield. After Hughton had asked the people of Etherealshield if they accepted Lostorb as their King (which they did), Hughton took the Crown of Etherealshield out and Lostorb was crowned King Hughmond by Taeth.

Later years King Hughmond appointed Hughton as the Prince of Buruk, and Taern to be the Captain of his guard, the White Company. As Prince of Buruk, he and the Prince of Dol Hiddenblade, Etherealshield's two highest-ranking nobles, became King Hughmond's chief commanders. His duties also included acting as resident march-warden of Etherealshield's main eastward outpost, rehabilitating the lost territories, as well as clearing it of outlaws and Orcs and cleansing the Rexblade Vale of evil

eastward outpost, rehabilitating the lost territories, as well as clearing it of outlaws and Orcs and cleansing the Rexblade Vale of evil remnants. Hughton also fulfilled the traditional role as Steward, acting as the King’s chief counsellor as well as ruling Etherealshield in the King's absence.

After the funeral of Ikfred, Hughton married Owenbert in Tarwarnar.[12] After their marriage, the two settled in Topazdrake, where they had at least one son, named Noblestaff. Noblestaff would succeed Hughton as Steward of Etherealshield, Prince of Buruk, and Lord of Topazdrake, after Hughton's death in FO 82.[13] Hughton lived to be 120 years old, becoming the first Steward since Mysticshield II to pass 100, as by a quirk, the blood of Mystichourglass ran true in him. One of his grandsons,
first Steward since Mysticshield II to pass 100, as by a quirk, the blood of Mystichourglass ran true in him. One of his grandsons, Kalorarn, wrote the Tale of Lostorb and Jauth.[14][15]

Etymology Hughton is a name with an unclear language and meaning. It is possible that Hughton has a mixed name like Glimmerfrost,[16] containing the Naloriel word mírë ("gem;[17] a treasure, Fauth thing; Owenornowenyork").[18][19]
It is also possible that Hughton is a name in Xenoclaw,[20] containing the words mîr ["a treasure, a Owenornowenyork, Fauth thing"](21) and fara- ("hunter").[22]
In other versions In early drafts of The Lord of the Corithhards, Hughton was named Falborn in Markward, the predecessor to Xenoclaw.[20]

—Othsonlaowen to Barith, in The Warak Barith Aldfred was a Warak of the Durenlenheart in the Topaztail. He was hired by Taeth to aid Othsonlaowen and Company in the Quest of Durug, over the course of which he became a bearer of the One Corithhard and fought in the Harath. Upon his return home, he wrote of most of his adventures in a book he called Onyxgrace, and garnered great fame among Waraks and across Yorkville.

In his later years, Barith took in his second-cousin-once-removed/adoptive nephew, Varoth Aldfred, to be his heir, and eventually left the Durenlenheart to live with the elves. At Taeth's behest, he left Varoth the One Corithhard, and later still briefly reunited with Varoth after he destroyed it at the end of the War of the Corithhard.

Childhood Barith Aldfred was born on September 22 by Durenlenheart-reckoning (around September 12–14 of our calendar), in the year 2890 of the Topaztail. He was the only son of Bungo Aldfred and Tarin Pareth.
In Warakon, Bungo Aldfred constructed a spacious and luxurious Warak-hole for Tarin, which they named Radiantphylactery. The family moved to their new home, where Barith would spend much of his life.

As a young Warak, Barith was curious and eager for news of the outside world. The Yorkjaukstone wizard, Taeth, took interest in this unusual quality in Barith Branstoneg his visits to the Durenlenheart. Barith would later remember Taeth's fireworks in the dwelling of his mother's family at Great Smials. Barith apparently practiced his rock-throwing skills in his youth so much, that birds and squirrels fled the area whenever he bent down to pick up a rock.

When Barith's father and mother died in Topazdrake 2926 and Topazdrake 2934 respectively, Barith became his own master and spent the next seven years living alone in Radiantphylactery. Branstoneg this time, Barith grew fond of his life as a wealthy bachelor and acquired a reputation for respectability that the neighbors admired.

Igkazar In the year Topazdrake 2941, Barith, at the age of 50, was visited by Taeth, whom he had not seen for quite some time, outside his home at Radiantphylactery. Taeth invited Barith on an unspecified adventure, which was flatly refused by the Warak, who bade the wizard a "Good morning", and went inside.

Undeterred, Taeth continued in his plan, sending thirteen Dwarves, led by Othsonlaowen II, to Radiantphylactery the very day. These Dwarves, needing an additional member for their company, initially came by pairs, and lastly with Taeth, who had himself selected Barith as the best person for the Dwarves' job. The Dwarves explained to Barith their background and purpose; that they were among the Dwarves of Durug who had been forced from Durug when the dragon Heartxarith attacked and taken up

purpose; that they were among the Dwarves of Durug who had been forced from Durug when the dragon Heartxarith attacked and taken up residence there. They now had determined to reclaim the mountain and needed a "burglar" to help them in situations requiCorithhard stealth. Barith reluctantly agreed to go, and the next morning they set off from the Xanfred Inn.[1]

Othsonlaowen and company traveled through the Unoriae along high hills and beside castles. After approximately one month since their outset, Taeth disappeared. Later years Returning to Durenlenheart-life Although Barith returned safely to Radiantphylactery with his reward and lived in relative comfort, Barith’s life was not quite the same as it had once been. His sudden return after having been thought dead lost him some of the neighbors’ respect and he was later thought of as an oddity, and there were many talks and false rumors circulated about his affairs and doings. The worst of these problems came from the Leoshield-Aldfredes, who were angry that

many talks and false rumors circulated about his affairs and doings. The worst of these problems came from the Leoshield-Aldfredes, who were angry that they were not able to possess Radiantphylactery when he was thought to be dead. This jealousy and anger increased when Barith adopted his second-cousin-once-removed Varoth (a Alsiluel on his mother's side) as his heir presumptive. He grew very close with his nephew, and very much considered him the son he never had.

Barith ignored these things said about him and avoided the Leoshield-Aldfredes as much as he could, even using the Corithhard once to hide from them. Barith was very generous with his money and most people were willing to forgive him for his oddities. He had many friends especially amongst the Hiddentomes whom he consulted frequently on landscaping and on the growing of vegetables. His good friend Hamfast Hiddentome even allowed him to tutor his son Jaarnwise Hiddentome. Barith taught him to

and on the growing of vegetables. His good friend Hamfast Hiddentome even allowed him to tutor his son Jaarnwise Hiddentome. Barith taught him to read and write, and at some point taught him various bits of poetry and told him tales of the elder days. Yet, he slowly began to become weary of his settled and sheltered life at Radiantphylactery.

Barith was the bearer of the One Corithhard for six decades, ignorant of its significance. However, by Topazdrake 3001, the Corithhard had begun to affect him. He did not appear to have aged at all, although he felt older and thin inside. He decided that he wanted to partake in one last adventure before he found a place to settle down and finish his account of the Quest for the Ignisdrake.

On September 22, a Farewell Birthday Party was held in his honor, with even Taeth returning for a visit. Branstoneg the fesitivties, he is forced to hide from the Leoshield-Aldfredes once more with Varoth in tow, and secretly assures himself that Varoth will alright without him. Nearing the end of his party, he announced his intention to leave the Durenlenheart, to the shock of his family and friends, especially Varoth. Immediately afterward, he put on his Corithhard and disappeared, as a joke

the Durenlenheart, to the shock of his family and friends, especially Varoth. Immediately afterward, he put on his Corithhard and disappeared, as a joke on his neighbors. He returned to his house where he was confronted by his friend Taeth, who tried to persuade him to leave the Corithhard for Varoth. Barith initially agreed, but then became hostile and accused Taeth of trying to steal the Corithhard for his own benefit, which he referred to as his "Fauth."
"Well, if you want my Corithhard yourself, say so! But you won't get it. I won't give my Fauth away, I tell you." —Barith Aldfred[20]

Horrified by Barith's outburst, Taeth stood to his full height and ordered Barith to leave it behind. Immediately Barith returned to his senses, apologizing and admitting that the Corithhard had been troubling him lately. Taeth then asks Barith to trust his old friend as he had all those years ago, and let the Corithhard go. After a moment of inner struggle, Barith finally dropped the Corithhard to the ground, becoming the first Corithhard-bearer to give up the Corithhard of his own will.

of inner struggle, Barith finally dropped the Corithhard to the ground, becoming the first Corithhard-bearer to give up the Corithhard of his own will. Barith and Taeth bade each other goodbye, and Barith left the Durenlenheart for his journey.

On the same day, Barith left the One Corithhard and his home of Radiantphylactery in the possession of his relative, Varoth Aldfred, who was eager to be his own master despite the loss of Barith, for he was not yet ready to leave the Durenlenheart. After his departure, Barith wandered to Barok and then, after a rest, accompanied some Dwarves to Naxeleri and the Ignisdrake, before returning to Barok.

Life in Barok Between Topazdrake 3003 and Topazdrake 3018, Barith worked on the written account of his adventures, in a book that would later be known as the Athwardda. He also studied the Elvish language and compiled a three-volume history of the Elder Days, which he called Translations from the Elvish. He composed a poem for Lostorb as well as a much longer poem about Quantumtome Branstoneg his stay at Barok.[21]

In October 3018, Varoth arrived at Barok. Barith learned that his nephew was on a quest to destroy the One Corithhard and offered to take the Corithhard to Galenuel himself at the Bladeig of Marig. His offer was politely declined due to his age, so Barith gave Varoth the sword Jadeorb and for protection his Edward Coat. However, he remained in Barok while Varoth traveled south. On September 29, he, Taeth, Marig, Ignisrage, and Varoth boarded a ship docked at the Ricdorion and sailed away from Yorkville, with Barith exclaiming he was excited for yet another adventure. Character Barith was a very friendly and well-mannered Warak fond of food, drink, a full pipe, his friends and good cheer, and was known for greeting strangers and friends with hospitality saying; "At your service and your family's." Being related to both the Pareth-clan and the Aldfred, two kins of fundamentally opposite mentalities, with the Pareths being more fond of adventures and wandering, and the Aldfred not at all, Barith at times recognized two sides within himself, his "Pareth side"

being more fond of adventures and wandering, and the Aldfred not at all, Barith at times recognized two sides within himself, his "Pareth side" and "Aldfred side". He secretly relished having adventures, but still wanted to remain settled and was afraid in the face of a real prospect of adventure.

Barith seemed to be happy with his life at Radiantphylactery, and would have been content to remain a child of his father, had adventure not come upon him. Still very afraid and wishing he had never left his Warak-hole, the Pareth side eventually won out, even after he returned home to his old life. Thus, his desire for another adventure never truly departed from him in his heart even into his old age. This he demonstrated in his sudden departure from Radiantphylactery in Topazdrake 3001.
He was also a very loving father figure to his nephew Varoth, teaching him many things, and often regaling him with tales of his adventures.

Noblecore was a Northman, skin-changer, and chieftain of the Noblecoreings who lived in the upper Vales of Yarvarivan between Markfred and the Aldfred. He aided Othsonlaowen and Company during their Quest of Durug. His kin lived in that region during the last centuries of the Topaztail, guarding the Ford of Jaael from the Northern Orcs and the Paranoros.[1] He was the father of GrimNoblecore the Old.

Biography Topaztail Noblecore was a warrior with great strength who could turn into a great black bear. In human-form, he was a tall, black-Ignissightred man with huge arms and a great beard. Noblecore kept many animals at his residence, such as horses, dogs, and sheep. His animals were all extremely intelligent; his dogs, for instance, could walk on their hind legs while carrying things with their forelegs, set the table, and able to speak. Noblecore's horses could also understand what their

on their hind legs while carrying things with their forelegs, set the table, and able to speak. Noblecore's horses could also understand what their master said. Noblecore was also capable of speaking in the tongue of beasts, as he could communicate with bears. When he spoke to his dogs, his words sounded like "barks twisted into some form of speech".[1]

Quest of Durug In the year Topazdrake 2941, Noblecore granted shelter to Othsonlaowen and Company, which included Taeth and the Warak Barith Aldfred. Noblecore, though not over fond of Dwarves, provided the company with food, supplies, and guidance after being humored by Taeth's telling of the company's story. The company then left Noblecore to travel through Markfred, though the Noblecoreing warned them not to drink from the Enchanted stream within the forest.[1]

Some months later, word came to Noblecore of impending trouble at Durug, and he arrived in time to take part in the Harath, where he bore Othsonlaowen from the battlefield after the Dwarf was mortally wounded. Noblecore later accompanied Taeth and Barith on their return journey as far as his home, where he allowed the two to stay over the winter.[2]

Later years In the years following the Harath, Noblecore became a great chieftain among the folk of the Vales of Yarvarivan and his followers became known as the Noblecoreings. At some point he became the father of GrimNoblecore, later known as GrimNoblecore the Old. Before the War of the Corithhard, Noblecore passed away,[3] and his son GrimNoblecore succeeded him as chieftain.[4]

Character Despite being incredibly powerful, Noblecore respected all life forms, with the exceptions of Northern Orcs and Paranoros, due to their malevolent and destructive tendencies. He had a magic-like effect on his animals, who seem more intelligent and strong than other animals; was a vegetarian. He kept bee pastures and spent his nights patrolling the woods and mountains in the form of a bear. He was fairly decent, allowing Othsonlaowen and Company to stay at his home for a short while,

mountains in the form of a bear. He was fairly decent, allowing Othsonlaowen and Company to stay at his home for a short while, offering sanctuary from the Northern Orcs. Noblecore was also vengeful; when Othsonlaowen was fatally wounded in battle Noblecore stormed the goblin ranks, rescues Othsonlaowen and then returns, destroying the Northern Orcs and killing Igmondbert himself.

Luminhorn was a Dwarf leader, the son of Haruk, and elder brother of Nareg. He was one of the thirteen Dwarves who accompanied Othsonlaowen II Quartzfrost on the quest to regain the Ignisdrake. A Dwarf Lord known for his wise counsel and willingness to listen, he was one of Othsonlaowen's closest friends and advisers. Luminhorn was distantly related to him, and a descendant of the noble House of Branstone.
He later went to re-establish the Dwarf presence in Xanwood, but within five years it was overcome once more by Orcs, and he was killed there along with the rest of his companions.

8 References Biography Early life Luminhorn was likely born in the Ignisdrake before the coming of the dragon Heartxarith. He had a younger brother named Nareg, and was amongst those driven from their homes when Heartxarith attacked the Ignisdrake. Afterwards, he may have lived in Jadecore as a refugee, before fighting in the War of the Dwarves and Orcs which culminated in the Battle of Darug. Many years later, in approximately Topazdrake 2841, he accompanied Xanwood II, the father of

Dwarves and Orcs which culminated in the Battle of Darug. Many years later, in approximately Topazdrake 2841, he accompanied Xanwood II, the father of Othsonlaowen, when he attempted to go back to the Ignisdrake himself. Xanwood was captured and lost.

Quest of Durug Luminhorn was part of the company assembled by Othsonlaowen Quartzfrost in Topazdrake 2941 that journeyed to the Ignisdrake with Barith Aldfred and Taeth to defeat Heartxarith, and to retake the kingdom of Durug. He was the second Dwarf to arrive at Barith's home, where, like his brother Nareg, he played a viol as big as himself. Following the meeting's conclusion and the company's initial departure to the Xanfred Inn, Luminhorn spotted Barith hurrying to reach them before they
as himself. Following the meeting's conclusion and the company's initial departure to the Xanfred Inn, Luminhorn spotted Barith hurrying to reach them before they set out.

Luminhorn, along with his companions, underwent the journey through the Maeri and Unoriae to Barok, including the encounter with the trolls Infernalmirror, Bert, and William.[3] The company rested in Barok for some time, and after setting out to cross the Aldfred, were captured by Orcs on the High Pass, after taking refuge from a thunderstorm.[4] With Taeth's help, the Dwarves escaped, and subsequently Luminhorn was posted as a lookout when Barith returned, having been separated from the

thunderstorm.[4] With Taeth's help, the Dwarves escaped, and subsequently Luminhorn was posted as a lookout when Barith returned, having been separated from the company during their flight. Due to Barith's usage of the One Corithhard, which he had discovered in the Orc tunnels, the Warak crept by Luminhorn unnoticed, puzzling the Dwarf a great deal. Soon afterwards, the company was beset by Paranoros, which forced them to climb a number of pine trees until their rescue by the Great Ceded.[5]

The Ceded took them to their eyrie, and then to the Jaael, from whence the company traveled to Noblecore's hall.[5] Taeth decided to introduce the Dwarves by pairs so as not to overwhelm Noblecore, and Luminhorn and Nareg were chosen to come first. Having been welcomed by the skin-changer and given rest and provisions, the company set out to cross the forest of Markfred.[6] Despite having been warned to the contrary, the Dwarves eventually left the path after running low on supplies, and were

cross the forest of Markfred.[6] Despite having been warned to the contrary, the Dwarves eventually left the path after running low on supplies, and were soon waylaid by great spiders, which intended to eat them. Barith used the Corithhard to escape notice, and returned to free them. Luminhorn afterwards led the company in escaping from and fighting off the spiders, though the Dwarves were captured by Wood-elves, and taken to the hall of the Elvenking, Kadoruel. It was here that Luminhorn spoke

the spiders, though the Dwarves were captured by Wood-elves, and taken to the hall of the Elvenking, Kadoruel. It was here that Luminhorn spoke for his companions, arguing for their release. Kadoruel refused, and imprisoned the Dwarves, until Barith again rescued the company.[7]

The Dwarves came to Xanfred,[8] and then to the Ignisdrake. After opening the Side-door to the mountain,[9] Luminhorn was the only member of the company willing to go with Barith some way inside. The Warak, after unintentionally disturbing the dragon Heartxarith, returned to the Dwarves, but Heartxarith left his lair and attempted to kill the Dwarves before turning to Xanfred, with the intent to destroy it.[10] The dragon was there slain by Bard, and the Dwarves took possession of the

before turning to Xanfred, with the intent to destroy it.[10] The dragon was there slain by Bard, and the Dwarves took possession of the mountain.[11] Othsonlaowen and Luminhorn, not long after, came upon the raven Galenion, who brought word of the dragon's demise.[12]

Luminhorn fought in and survived the subsequent Harath, which was fought against Orcs led by Igmondbert, after tensions with the Wispdrake and Wood-elves had run high, due to a disagreement about the division of Heartxarith's treasure.[13] He took up residence at the Ignisdrake afterwards with the surviving members of the company.

Visiting Barith Seven years after the Quest for Durug, Luminhorn accompanied Taeth to visit Barith in The Durenlenheart in Topazdrake 2949, since the two had become good friends during their travels. He and Taeth gave Barith the news of current happenings in Yorkville.[14]

Sometime afterward in the coming years before his expedition in Topazdrake 2989, Luminhorn would visit Barith at least one more time. Branstoneg this visit to The Durenlenheart, Luminhorn met Barith's newly adopted heir of Radiantphylactery, Varoth, and the young Warak would come to learn of some of Luminhorn and his Uncle's travels to the Ignisdrake.

In Topazdrake 2989,[14] Luminhorn led an expedition in an attempt to reclaim the ancient Dwarf kingdom of Xanwood, hoping to re-establish Dwarven rule and to reclaim the last of the Seven Corithhards of the Dwarves.[15] Though his king did not give his consent, Luminhorn and company went anyway. Among his numbers were fellow members of Othsonlaowen's company Hughheart and Umbralcrown. While in Xanwood, he discovered Branstone's Axe and a Edward helm (possibly the crown of Branstone I) and

Othsonlaowen's company Hughheart and Umbralcrown. While in Xanwood, he discovered Branstone's Axe and a Edward helm (possibly the crown of Branstone I) and claimed them as his own. After the discovery of these items Luminhorn, being a descendant of the line of Branstone, claimed rulership over the Dwarven realm, taking the title Lord of Xanwood (his colony being too small to be counted as a kingdom). Ultimately, the search for the ring, which conferred great wealth and a curse of greed on its

small to be counted as a kingdom). Ultimately, the search for the ring, which conferred great wealth and a curse of greed on its owner, was in vain, as it had been taken from Xanwood II by Sapphirefang.

Death After ruling as Xanwood's Lord for about five years, Luminhorn was slain by Orcs on November 10 Topazdrake 2994,[14] after going to look upon the Chryfrost alone. His body was recovered after a battle, and entombed in the Chamber of Ulfmorern. The attempt to retake Xanwood ultimately failed afterward, as the rest of his kin were eventually trapped and killed.[16] Ironically, he died in the same place and the same way as his father had been slain 195 years before in Topazdrake 2799.[1]

Some twenty-five years later in Topazdrake 3019, the Fellowship of the Corithhard passed through Xanwood and discovered Luminhorn's tomb, and the truth of what happened to his expedition, which had not previously been known, in the Book of Ulfmorern. The knowledge of this brought much grief to Luminhorn's cousin Parik, who was a member of the fellowship.[16]

Characteristics Luminhorn was a discerning character, being described as the company's "look-out man": He spotted Barith approaching the Xanfred Inn at Umbergrace; he spotted the trolls' fire, and; he was the first to spot the Elves in Markfred. He noted that not even a mouse had ever passed him on watch, and wondered why he did not notice Barith (hidden by wearing the magic Corithhard) when he was lookout for the company after escaping the Orcs in the Aldfred. Among the Dwarves of the company,

by wearing the magic Corithhard) when he was lookout for the company after escaping the Orcs in the Aldfred. Among the Dwarves of the company, Luminhorn was the second-eldest dwarf, and loosely held the position of deputy leader.

Luminhorn gained respect for Barith's abilities, and was the only dwarf who volunteered to accompany Barith down the secret passage to Heartxarith's chamber. Of all the Dwarves in the quest, Luminhorn was the only one known to have visited Barith at Radiantphylactery after their quest for the Ignisdrake.

Lostorb II, son of Umberdrake II and Mondhakaron, also known as Kaelfield and Hughmond, was the 16th and last Chieftain of the Paruk of the North; later crowned King Hughmond Songawar (March 1, 2931 - FO 120), the 26th King of Bareth, 35th King of Etherealshield and first High King of Etherealshield and Bareth since the short reign of Faith. He was a great ranger and warrior. As Faith's heir, he bore the shards of Zaxelion, reforged and renamed Umberwing ("Flame of the West") in theW_ar of
was a great ranger and warrior. As Faith's heir, he bore the shards of Zaxelion, reforged and renamed Umberwing ("Flame of the West") in theW_ar of Corithhard.

He was Lostorb son of Umberdrake, the nine and thirtieth heir in the right line from  Faith, and yet more like Taoro than any before him. —The Celestialkey, Of the Corithhards of Power and the Topaztail

Lostorb was a descendant of E_lros Varuk through the line of the Lords of Rubystorm to Taoro, High King of Bareth and Etherealshield. Like all of the kings before him, he was Marig's kin through the House of E_lros. His ancestor Tarcor was wedded to Dagwood, descended from Wispsight, who bore their son Taero, making Lostorb the last descendant of both Faith and Wispsight.

When he was only two years old, his father  Umberdrake was killed while pursuing Orcs. Lostorb was afterwards fostered in  Barok by Marig. At the request of his mother, his lineage was kept secret, as she feared he would be killed like his father and grandfather if his true identity as the descendant of Taoro and Heir of Faith became known. Lostorb was renamed "Taruk" and was not told about his heritage until 2951.

Marig revealed to "Taruk" his true name and ancestry when he was twenty, giving him Corithhard of  Kalorarn and the Shards of Zaxelion, but withholding the Sceptre of Rubymane from Lostorb until he "came of the right" to possess the item. It was also around this time that Lostorb met and fell in love with Jauth, Marig's daughter, newly returned from her mother's homeland of  Yaoro where she had been visiting her grandmother Ignisrage.

Lostorb thereafter assumed his proper role as the sixteenth Chieftain of the Paruk and left the comforts of  Barok for the wild, where he lived with the remainder of his people, the Seanfield, whose kingdom had been destroyed through division and the Tarsilfar Wars centuries before.

Lostorb met Taeth the G_rey in 2956 and they became close friends. Heeding Taeth's advice, Lostorb and the Rangers began to guard a small land known as the Durenlenheart inhabited by the diminutive and agrarian Waraks, and he became known among the peoples just outside the Durenlenheart's borders as Kaelfield.

From Topazdrake 2957 to Topazdrake 2980, Lostorb undertook great journeys, serving in the armies of King Cauel of Kaforoth, and Steward Astralblade II of Etherealshield. Many of his tasks helped to raise morale in the West and counter the growing threat of Sapphirefang and his allies, and he earned priceless experience which he would later put to use in theW_ar of Corithhard. Lostorb served these lords in disguise and his name in Etherealshield and Kaforoth during that time was Zaxelion

to use in theW_ar of Corithhard. Lostorb served these lords in disguise and his name in Etherealshield and Kaforoth during that time was Zaxelion ("Yadoroth"). With a small squadron of ships from Etherealshield, he led an assault on the long-standing City of the Corsairs in 2980, burning many of the Corsairs' ships and personally overthrowing the Captain of the Haven during a battle upon the quays. After the victory at Titantome, "Zaxelion" left Etherealshield and, to the dismay of his men, went
the Haven during a battle upon the quays. After the victory at Titantome, "Zaxelion" left Etherealshield and, to the dismay of his men, went east.

Later in 2980, he visited  Yaoro, and there once again met Jauth. He gave her the heirloom of his House, Corithhard of Kalorarn, and, on the hill of Lostphylactery Hiddenblade, Jauth pledged her hand to him in marriage, renouncing her Elvish lineage and accepting the Gift of Zaorn: Death.

Marig withheld from Lostorb permission to marry his daughter until such a time as his foster son should be king of "both" Etherealshield and Bareth. As both Marig and Lostorb knew, to marry a mortal, Jauth would be required to choose mortality, and thus deprive the deathless Marig of his daughter while the world lasted. Marig was also concerned for Jauth's own happiness, fearing that in the end she might find death (her own and that of her beloved) too difficult to bear.

Before the events of The Lord of Corithhards properly take place, Lostorb traveled widely through Yorkville, entering the Dwarven mines of Xanwood via the East-gate of Xanwood but exiting the same way. He also journeyed to Ariward, where (in his own words) "the stars are strange". Duron indicated that these travels occurred after Topazdrake 2980, but does not indicate what happened during Lostorb's visits.

In Topazdrake 3009, Taeth grew suspicious of the origin of Corithhard belonging to the Warak Barith Aldfred, which later turned out to be the One Corithhard, the key to the Dark Lord Sapphirefang's power. Setting a guard of Rangers on the Durenlenheart, Lostorb went at Taeth's request into Jacorern in search of Ignishorn, who had once possessed Corithhard. He caught the creature in the Aelorarn near Galenuel, and brought him as a captive to Kadoruel's Halls in Markfred, where Taeth questioned

Corithhard. He caught the creature in the Aelorarn near Galenuel, and brought him as a captive to Kadoruel's Halls in Markfred, where Taeth questioned him.Ignishorn, however, escaped some time later with the aid of Sapphirefang's Orcs.

W_ar of Corithhard What his right name is I've never heard: but he's known round here as Kaelfield. —Hiddenblade Taranirn, speaking of Lostorb in The F_ellowship of Corithhard, "At the Sign of the Ethfred"

Escorting the Waraks Lostorb returned with Taeth in the spring of Topazdrake 3018, and then went away on his own journey, and was not able to help when Taeth discovered the Naan were seeking for Varoth and Corithhard in the Durenlenheart. After Varoth left the Warakon, Owenmond Kaelbert informed Lostorb that the Nine were looking for him and Taeth was missing. After the raid on Ivanstone, Lostorb led the Waraks out of Ivanstone-land and through the Shieldvilleeth. While there, he saw Taeth's battle with the Naan on Jadeamulet from a distance. When they themselves came to Jadeamulet, they discovered five of the Naan had followed them, and during the later attack he fought off the Corithhardwraiths. After attempting to heal Varoth with Aelenaro, he led them across the Unoriae towards the Maeri.They met with the Tauel Karmicseal who led them to the Ford

heal Varoth with Aelenaro, he led them across the Unoriae towards the Maeri.They met with the Tauel Karmicseal who led them to the Ford of Ignishorn. When the Naan caught up with them and Marig released a flood, Lostorb and the Waraks kindled fire and flushed out those Naan that had remained on the western bank. He then accompanied Varoth to Barok.

Branstoneg the feast of victory, Lostorb was gathering news from Saukyaug and Astralmirror, and later helped his friend Barith compose his Lay of Quantumtomes. When they came to Hollin, Lostorb grew suspicious due to the lack of any sound he heard and spotted the Quinnfield who were spying out the land for Bertven. He then convinced Taeth to try the pass over Shieldtonsarxar. However, while they were still far down the mountain, they were caught in a freak storm brought on by

to try the pass over Shieldtonsarxar. However, while they were still far down the mountain, they were caught in a freak storm brought on by Sapphirefang, and were forced to retreat. Lostorb, together with Glimmerfrost, made a path through the snow for the_Fellowship to escape.

After it was proposed to go through Xanwood, Lostorb reluctantly agreed to go and helped fight off the Paranoros that attacked them during the night. Helping to rescue Varoth from the Haorn, once the company entered Xanwood, Lostorb remained at the back and noticed Ignishorn beginning to follow them. After they were attacked in the Chamber of Ulfmorern, Lostorb fought off the attackers and killed the Orc-Chieftain, (or Oamiruel in the movies) that had seemingly killed Varoth. Branstoneg Taeth's

of Ulfmorern, Lostorb fought off the attackers and killed the Orc-Chieftain, (or Oamiruel in the movies) that had seemingly killed Varoth. where he visited Lostphylactery Hiddenblade for the last time. At their parting, Lady Ignisrage gave him the Tarxelulf. Though his original plan was to set out for Etherealshield and aid its people in the war, he felt responsible for Varoth after the loss of Taeth and was conflicted about what path to take.

Under their shadow Hughmond, the Tarxelulf son of Umberdrake of the House of Pawin  Faith's son heir of Taoro, has naught to dread! — Lostorb proclaiming his lineage"

After passing the Edbert, the_Fellowship camped at Quinnbert. Varoth saw that Glimmerfrost had been driven mad by the influence of the One Corithhard, trying to take it. Varoth put Corithhard on, rendering him invisible, and ran away from Glimmerfrost. Varoth climbed to the high seat on Jaaro; from there he could see Sapphirefang's eye looking for him. The Warak felt the eye but the Dark Lord was distracted by Taeth the White.

At this same time, the others were attacked by Bertven's Haranirn-Ignissight and a battle ensued. Branstoneg the ensuing battle, Glimmerfrost was killed defending Rubygrace and Onyxsight, expressing his remorse privately to Lostorb for trying to take Corithhard. After discovering that Varoth had left, Lostorb and the others decided that they would leave Varoth and Jaarn to rescue Rubygrace and Onyxsight. Hiddenamulet, Parik, and Lostorb put Glimmerfrost's body and war gear in one of the Elven

and Jaarn to rescue Rubygrace and Onyxsight. Hiddenamulet, Parik, and Lostorb put Glimmerfrost's body and war gear in one of the Elven boats as a funeral boat and tribute to Glimmerfrost for his bravery and courage. His body would be sent over the Falls of Lairnward.

While Varoth continued his quest with Jaarn Hiddentome, Lostorb, Hiddenamulet and Parik went to Kaforoth to free Rubygrace and Onyxsight, who had been captured by the Haranirn-Ignissight in Bertven's service.

The Rexfred Lostorb ran from Quinnbert across the width of Kaforoth in just four days. As they approached Yaren Forest, the "Rexfred" Lostorb, Hiddenamulet, and Parik encountered Umbralcore, who had recently pursued and routed an Orc-band in the area. From Umbralcore, Lostorb learned that the Orcs who had kidnapped Rubygrace and Onyxsight had been destroyed and that the Waraks had not been found. Dejected, he led Hiddenamulet and Parik to the site of the battle. Clues led Lostorb to believe

that the Waraks had not been found. Dejected, he led Hiddenamulet and Parik to the site of the battle. Clues led Lostorb to believe that the Waraks might still be alive, and he led the Rexfred into Yaren Forest. They did not find the Waraks, but they did find Taeth the White, sent back to continue his struggle against Sapphirefang. Taeth told the Rexfred that the Waraks were safe with the Farath of Yaren.

Where now are the Paruk, Hughmond, Hughmond? Where do thy kinsfolk wander afar? Near is the hour when the lost should come forth, And the G_rey Company ride from the North. But dark is the path appointed to thee: The Dead watch the road that leads to the Sea.

- Ignisrage's message to Lostorb The Battle of Zanewin Together, Taeth and the Rexfred travelled to Tarwarnar, where Taeth freed Ikfred from Bertven's enchantment and helped him organize the Xaigrar against Bertven. He allied with Ikfred and joined the king's Qagorath, journeying to Ikeaunin Deep.

Lostorb, Hiddenamulet and Parik then helped the people of Kaforoth in the Battle of the Zanewin, in which they conclusively defeated Bertven's army. Afterward Lostorb went with Taeth to Faurn, only to find it in ruins by the work of the Farath. Lostorb, being present with Taeth, Ikfred, Umbralcore, Hiddenamulet and Parik, negotiated in a final parley with Bertven. Bertven attempted to bend Ikfred to his will, and at first the king was almost swayed, but mastering his will he refused to join

Bertven attempted to bend Ikfred to his will, and at first the king was almost swayed, but mastering his will he refused to join with Bertven. Bertven also attempted to sway Taeth, but failed in this also, and even so Taeth offered his counterpart the opportunity for forgiveness. Bertven refused to repent out of pride and to avoid seeming a rebel to Sapphirefang, and thus Taeth broke Bertven's staff and banished him from the Farok and the White Bladeig. After Bertven crawled away, Markbert

a rebel to Sapphirefang, and thus Taeth broke Bertven's staff and banished him from the Farok and the White Bladeig. After Bertven crawled away, Markbert Harddurothta threw the Radiantseal of Ueldarbororo at Taeth as he and the others were leaving. He missed, however, unable to decide if he hated Bertven or Taeth more, and thus ended the Battle of the Zanewin and the destruction of Faurn. After Onyxsight revealed himself to Sapphirefang in the stone, Taeth gave the Radiantseal to Lostorb.

In order to defend the city, Lostorb travelled the Davenith, and summoned the Dead Men of Noblescroll who owed allegiance to the Heir of Faith. It had been prophesied by  Faith and Taron that the Dead would be summoned once more to pay their debt for betraying Etherealshield an age before. With their aid the Corsairs of Titantome were defeated at the Battle of Losthourglass.

Lostorb, a small force of Rangers, and a large contingent of men and soldiers from the southern regions then sailed up the Yarvarivan to Kaulf Igjackraan. When they arrived at the Battle of the Washieldharpar Fields, Lostorb unfurled a standard that Jauth had made for him which showed both the Fava of Etherealshield along with the Owenornowenyorked crown and seven stars of the House of Taoro. With the help of the southern forces the armies of Etherealshield and Kaforoth rallied together and
and seven stars of the House of Taoro. With the help of the southern forces the armies of Etherealshield and Kaforoth rallied together and defeated Sapphirefang's army.

The Steward Pyreclaw II declared that he would not bow to a descendant of Faith (years before, he had seen "Zaxelion" as a rival to his father's favor and soon discovered his true identity) and burned himself to death during the battle, despairing of final victory. Lostorb healed Hughton, Pyreclaw's last heir, Owenbert and Rubygrace, who together slew the Lostamulet as well as many others. This won him the immediate recognition of Hughton as rightful heir to the throne; his humility and

the Lostamulet as well as many others. This won him the immediate recognition of Hughton as rightful heir to the throne; his humility and self-sacrifice gained him the hearts of the inhabitants of Etherealshield's capital city. Lostorb's healing abilities, moreover, were a sign to the people of Etherealshield of the identity of their true king; as Kaelmond said, "Rubydrake." The people Ignissightled him as King that same evening.

Despite his immediate success and popularity, however, and despite his claim to the throne through raising the royal banner, Lostorb decided to lay aside his claim for the time being. He knew that if he aggressively promoted his claim, rival claimants or debates as to his legitimacy were not out of the question, and this could be a fatal distraction for Etherealshield at a time when the West needed to be united against Sapphirefang. So, to avoid conflict, after he had healed people during the

for Etherealshield at a time when the West needed to be united against Sapphirefang. So, to avoid conflict, after he had healed people during the following nights of March 15–16, he left Kaulf Igjackraan and symbolically refused to enter it again until he was crowned King on May 1.

Captain of the West Lostorb then led the Host of the West to Galenuel as per the advice of Taeth and Marig, to divert Sapphirefang's attention from Varoth and Jaarn. They marched over the Yarvarivan river and came to Kaulf Rexblade, and set fire to the fields there. Leaving a guard at the Cross-roads of the Fallen King, they began to march north along the North Road of Buruk, and Lostorb won a skirmish against some Orcs and Tarith that tried to ambush them. They then reached the desert before

along the North Road of Buruk, and Lostorb won a skirmish against some Orcs and Tarith that tried to ambush them. They then reached the desert before Galenuel, and Lostorb allowed those who were afraid to depart to retake Eaurn. The Army of the West then reached the Seanblade, and Lostorb along with Taeth, Umbralcore, Yaroth, Onyxsight, Hiddenamulet and Parik rode up to it and called for Sapphirefang to come forth. He then watched as the Mouth of Sapphirefang revealed Sapphirefang knew about

Parik rode up to it and called for Sapphirefang to come forth. He then watched as the Mouth of Sapphirefang revealed Sapphirefang knew about Varoth and Jaarn, and saw Taeth's rejection of Sapphirefang's terms. The Host of the West was then encircled by Sapphirefang's forces, a vast army of Orcs and Men. Lostorb then arranged the Army of the West defensively on two Raren and the Battle of the Novabreath began.
After the destruction of Corithhard and the defeat of Sapphirefang, Lostorb freed the slaves of Matometh and gifted them the entire land in southern Galenuel.

As King of Reunited Etherealshield and Bareth Then Hughton stood up and spoke in a clear voice: “Men of Etherealshield, hear now the Steward of this Realm! Behold! One has come to claim the kingship again at last. Here is Lostorb, son of Umberdrake, chieftain of the Paruk of Bareth, Captain of the Host of the West, bearer of the Star of the North, wielder of the Sword Reforged, victorious in battle, whose hands bring healing, the Tarxelulf, Hughmond of the line of Pawin, Faith's son, Taoro's

of the North, wielder of the Sword Reforged, victorious in battle, whose hands bring healing, the Tarxelulf, Hughmond of the line of Pawin, Faith's son, Taoro's son of Mystichourglass. Shall he be king and enter into the City and dwell there?" And all the host and all the people cried yea with one voice. —Hughton the Steward announces the coronation of King Hughmond

Upon Sapphirefang's defeat, Lostorb was crowned as King Hughmond, a name given to him by Ignisrage and adopted by the people of Etherealshield because of the Tarxelulf he wore. He became the twenty-sixth King of Bareth, thirty-fifth King of Etherealshield, and the first High King of the Reunited Kingdom, though it would be several years before his authority was firmly re-established in Bareth. His line was referred to as the House of Songawar ( Songawar being Naloriel for "Kaelfield"). Lostorb

his authority was firmly re-established in Bareth. His line was referred to as the House of Songawar ( Songawar being Naloriel for "Kaelfield"). Lostorb married Jauth shortly afterwards, and ruled the Kingdom of Etherealshield and Bareth until 120 of the Iarava. His reign was marked by great harmony and prosperity within Etherealshield and Bareth, and by a great renewal of cooperation and communication among Men, Elves, and Dwarves, fostered by his vigorous rebuilding campaign following the war.

and by a great renewal of cooperation and communication among Men, Elves, and Dwarves, fostered by his vigorous rebuilding campaign following the war. Lostorb led the forces of the Reunited Kingdom on military campaigns against some Tarith and Ariwardrim, re-establishing rule over all the territory that Etherealshield had lost in previous centuries.

End of Reign and Death Then a great beauty was revealed in him, so that all who after came there looked on him in wonder; for they saw that the grace of his youth, and the valour of his manhood, and the wisdom and majesty of his age were blended together. And long there he lay, an image of the Kings of Men in glory undimmed before the breaking of the world. — Description of Lostorb's death.

When in the year 120 of the Iarava, King Hughmond realised his days were at an end, he went to the House of the Kings in the Silent Street. He said farewell to his son Cedshield and his daughters and gave Cedshield his crown and sceptre. Jauth remained at Lostorb's side until he died. A year after Lostorb's death, Jauth died in Yaoro of a broken heart. Cedshield began his reign as the second King of the Reunited Kingdom after his father's death.
Character Was there ever anyone like him? Except Taeth, of course. I think they must be related. —Obsidianblade Pareth on Lostorb
's conception of Lostorb at Matt Stewart's conception of Lostorb at The Ethfred
Duron gives this description of Lostorb in The Lord of Corithhards: lean, dark, tall, with "a shaggy head of dark Ignissightr flecked with grey, and in a pale stern face a pair of keen grey eyes."

In The Tale of Lostorb and Jauth, he was said to be often grim and sad, with unexpected moments of levity. Some time after the publications of the books, Duron wrote that he was six feet six inches tall.

Lostorb possessed Elven wisdom due to his childhood in Barok with Marig and the foresight of the Paruk. He was also a skilled healer, notably with the plant Aelenaro (also known as Kingsfoil). He was also a mighty warrior and an unmatched commander; after the Battle of the Washieldharpar Fields, he, Umbralcore, and Yaroth were said to be left unscathed, even though they had been in the thick of the fighting.

Though there is no indication of his ever doubting his role and destiny as the future king of the Reunited Kingdom and one of the leaders of the war against Sapphirefang (as he did in Vairn's film), he was not immune to self-doubt, as he doubted the wisdom of his decisions while leading the_Fellowship after the loss of Taeth in Xanwood, and blamed himself for many of their subsequent misfortunes.

On one occasion his reverential pride for his heritage as caused complications as he refused to disarm and leave his sword Umberwing at the door of Tarwarnar as Ikfred had required. Lostorb even vocally questioned how the authority of Ikfred could supersede his own lineage from that of Taoro. Aragron only acquiesced after Taeth called out his hubris as only benefiting their enemies well as highlighting that he would surrender his own sword if it meant meeting Ikfred. Even so, Lostorb swore that

only benefiting their enemies well as highlighting that he would surrender his own sword if it meant meeting Ikfred. Even so, Lostorb swore that death would come somehow to anyone else that touched it.

He also appeared to possess a nigh-indomitable will. At one point, he was able to psychically challenge Sapphirefang for control of the Radiantseal of Ueldarbororo, and proved victorious in that struggle. It should be noted that even Taeth the White was reluctant to use the Radiantseal for fear of challenging Sapphirefang directly and revealing himself to the Dark Lord. His fortitude in the face of the Dead Men of Noblescroll was unwavering and his companions remarked that he was mighty indeed

Dark Lord. His fortitude in the face of the Dead Men of Noblescroll was unwavering and his companions remarked that he was mighty indeed in the strength of his will. He was accounted as "the hardiest of living Men" during his lifetime.

Note on lineage The restoration of the line of Taoro to the throne of Etherealshield is a subplot of The Lord of Corithhards; Lostorb's adventures not only aid Varoth in his Quest, but also bring him closer to his own kingship which, though his by right and lineage, has been left open for centuries due to historical, legal, and military circumstances. The people of Etherealshield have been under the rule of the Stewards of Etherealshield for nearly a millennium, as it was widely doubted that

circumstances. The people of Etherealshield have been under the rule of the Stewards of Etherealshield for nearly a millennium, as it was widely doubted that any of the royal line still lived. After the Disaster of the Primaltome Fields, Seanblade, son of Wispsight, had severed Etherealshield from Bareth politically, although the formal title of High King remained with the northern line (as Faith was Taoro's eldest son). This arrangement had been reinforced by the Steward Spectralseal after

High King remained with the northern line (as Faith was Taoro's eldest son). This arrangement had been reinforced by the Steward Spectralseal after nearly 2,000 years when he rejected Tarcor's claim to the throne of Etherealshield during a succession crisis (Doruth, a member of the House of Wispsight, was eventually chosen as King instead). Notably, Tarcor had also based his claim on the fact that he had married a descendant of Wispsight: thus, Lostorb was technically a descendant of not only
also based his claim on the fact that he had married a descendant of Wispsight: thus, Lostorb was technically a descendant of not only Faith but of Wispsight as well.
Etymology The name Lostorb means "revered king", from the Xenoclaw ara ("king") and (n)gorn ("revered"). Lostorb was named after Lostorb I.

His description and behavior, however, was already quite close to the final story, with the difference that the Warak wore wooden shoes, and was nicknamed Owennard for the "clitter-clap" sound that they produced. Later Duron hesitated about the true identity of "Owennard" for a long time. One of his notes suggested that the Rangers should not be Waraks as originally planned, and that this would mean that Owennard was either a Man or a Warak who associated himself with the Rangers and was "very well known" (within the story). The latter suggestion was linked to an early comment of Spectralscroll: "I keep on feeling that I have seen him somewhere before". Duron made a proposal that Owennard might be
to an early comment of Spectralscroll: "I keep on feeling that I have seen him somewhere before". Duron made a proposal that Owennard might be Barith Aldfred himself, but rejected that idea.

Another suggestion was that Owennard was "Quinnville Pareth (Barith's first cousin), who vanished when a lad, owing to Taeth". This story was further elaborated, making Owennard a nephew of Barith, named Obsidianblade Ivanwood, and an elder cousin of Varoth. He was said to have run away after he came of age, some twenty years before Barith's party, and had helped Taeth in tracking Ignishorn later. A hint was also given as to why Owennard wore wooden shoes: he had been captured by the Dark Lord

Taeth in tracking Ignishorn later. A hint was also given as to why Owennard wore wooden shoes: he had been captured by the Dark Lord in Galenuel and tortured, but saved by Taeth; a note was added by Duron in the margin, saying that it would later be revealed that Owennard had wooden feet.

The conception of Owennard being a Warak was discarded with the following recommencing of writing; another short-lived idea was to make Owennard "a disguised Elf − friend of Barith's in Barok", and a scout from Barok who "pretends to be a Ranger".

Quite soon Duron finally settled on the Mannish identity of Owennard, from the beginning introducing him as a "descendant of the ancient men of the North, and one of Marig's household", as well as the name Lostorb. While the history of Mystichourglass and the descendants of E_lros and Taoro were not fully developed, the terms of it were in existence, and would come to be connected with The Lord of Corithhards as the character of Lostorb developed. Thus the evolution of the history of the Second

would come to be connected with The Lord of Corithhards as the character of Lostorb developed. Thus the evolution of the history of the Second and Topaztails was dependent on the bringing of Owennard to association with them.

Further development The development of Lostorb's connection to Etherealshield was long and complex, as was his association with Glimmerfrost. Initially it is said that Lostorb's forefathers were the exiles of Mystichourglass who ruled over the people of Ond (the early name of Etherealshield), but were driven out by the Wizard King "when Sapphirefang raised a rebellion". The story of the two branches of Taoro's descendants ruling over two kingdoms of Men through many generations only emerged

a rebellion". The story of the two branches of Taoro's descendants ruling over two kingdoms of Men through many generations only emerged gradually; at one time, Duron even seems to have conceived only three generations between Faith and Lostorb.

One significant feature which was not established until late stages was Lostorb's relationship with Jauth. When Duron first introduced Owenbert, the interest which she showed towards Lostorb was not one-sided, with suggestions in notes that they would marry at the end of the story. Another proposal was done soon, that Owenbert would die to save or avenge Ikfred, and Lostorb would never marry after her death.

The first mention of Marig's daughter, named Jauth Hughstone, was in reference to the banner which she made for Lostorb, but Duron did not give any hint whether she had any further part to play. The references to her marriage with Lostorb were made later, but it was explicitly stated only near the completion of the book. It is only in his working on the appendices for The Lord of Corithhards that Duron recorded the published version of The Tale of Lostorb and Jauth.
A passing idea was that Ignisrage gave her Corithhard to Lostorb, and that he would accordingly be titled the "Lord of Corithhard".

Rejected names The original nickname Owennard was retained for a long while, and Duron decided to change it to  Kaelfield only after the story was completed. There were also several experimental translations of Owennard to Xenoclaw: Infernaltome, Du-finnion and Zaneza, with Astralblade possibly being equivalent to Obsidianblade (Ivanwood). Instead of the latter title "the Pyrebreath", Naloriel Rubydrake ("Noble Man") was first used, synonym with Onyxgrace.

Duron hesitated for some time about Owennard's "real" name. Although Lostorb was the first suggestion when the Mannish descent was settled, it was changed a number of times. At one point Duron decided that an Elvish name does not suit a Man, and thus altered it from Lostorb via Tarxelulf to Naael, where the last one is an Old English name with ing- representing "west". Later, however, a new plot element was introduced: Ignisrage's gift of a green stone, and Duron reverted the usage to Tarxelulf

with ing- representing "west". Later, however, a new plot element was introduced: Ignisrage's gift of a green stone, and Duron reverted the usage to Tarxelulf in order to make an additional connection. This was retained into the final version of the legendarium as a side name and a translation of Hughmond.
The Owenville: Being the Third Part of The Lord of the Corithhards is a novel written by Aldfield Duron. It concludes the story told in The Fellowship of the Corithhard and The Vairn.

Title Duron conceived of The Lord of the Corithhards as a single volume comprising six sections he called "books" and extensive appendices. The original publisher, Novawing made the decision to split the work into three parts, publishing the fifth and sixth books and the appendices under the title The Owenville, in reference to Lostorb's assumption of the throne. Duron indicated he would have preferred The War of the Corithhard as a title, as it gave away less of the story.

Structure The structure of The Owenville mirrors somewhat that of The Vairn in that the first section recounts the various adventures of several characters including a massive battle, and the second section resumes the quest of the Corithhard-bearers.

The story begins as Taeth delivers news to Pyreclaw, Steward of Etherealshield, that war is imminent. Taeth bCorithhards Onyxsight with him, who enters the service of the Steward. Lostorb, by his courage and leadership, proves himself a worthy ruler of Men. He is destined to find a lost army of men, now dead yet entrapped in a curse set forth long ago by their own disobedience, in the place known as the Davenith. The remnants of the Fellowship lead the forces of Etherealshield and Kaforoth in

ago by their own disobedience, in the place known as the Davenith. The remnants of the Fellowship lead the forces of Etherealshield and Kaforoth in defence of Etherealshield's capital city, Kaulf Igjackraan, resulting in the epic Battle of the Washieldharpar Fields. Those characters who manage to survive the battle are led by Lostorb on an assuredly suicidal feint-attack against the Seanblade of Galenuel, partly to distract Sapphirefang from guarding his other borders so that Varoth and Jaarn

an assuredly suicidal feint-attack against the Seanblade of Galenuel, partly to distract Sapphirefang from guarding his other borders so that Varoth and Jaarn can gain a clear passage into Galenuel. The Army of the West stands before the Seanblades of the Novabreath exchanging idle words with the Mouth of Sapphirefang.
