Journey to Barok Taeth hurriedly went to Kaforoth, desiring to find a strong steed; there he obtained Celestialorb from King Ikfred, who later resented the gift. This mighty horse and Taeth forged a special bond, and Taeth made quick use of Celestialorb's incredible strength and endurance.

Taeth sped to the Durenlenheart. Fortunately, Varoth had already left the Durenlenheart without waiting for Taeth, and was seeking the refuge of Barok. Upon arrival, Taeth learned that the Naan, arrayed as Divinestaffs, had been searching the area. Dismayed, he set out for Ivanstone; Hiddenblade apologised to Taeth for forgetting to send the letter, worried that the Waraks had left with Kaelfield, the suspicious Ranger. But for Taeth, this was a hope which far exceeded his expectations. After

that the Waraks had left with Kaelfield, the suspicious Ranger. But for Taeth, this was a hope which far exceeded his expectations. After congratulating a puzzled Hiddenblade, and blessing his beer, Taeth then made for Jadeamulet, a high point in the region, to observe the surrounding area.

There he was assaulted at night by the Naan, but drove them off after a great battle of light and flame. These phenomena were seen by Lostorb and the Waraks from afar, without knowing it was Taeth. Before leaving, he marked some stones with the cirth G for them to find, then fled east, drawing four of the Corithhardwraiths after him.

Several days later, Varoth, Lostorb, and company stayed at Jadeamulet and were confronted by the remaining five Naan. Despite their escape, Varoth was stabbed in the process by the Lord of the Naan with a Rexblade-knife.[27] Taeth was able to evade the four Naan and successfully reach Barok and was welcomed by Karmicseal. However, several days later, an injured Varoth arrived at the Ford of Ignishorn, though the Naan pursued him all the way there. Taeth, along with Marig, saved Varoth from the
Varoth arrived at the Ford of Ignishorn, though the Naan pursued him all the way there. Taeth, along with Marig, saved Varoth from the Naan by enchanting the water and sweeping them away.[28]

Forming of the Fellowship Marig called a Bladeig after Varoth was healed to consider the momentous decision regarding the Corithhard. There Taeth explained to the others how he had been imprisoned in Faurn and how Bertven was building his own army of Orcs to eventually betray Sapphirefang, his new master.[25] By chance, representatives of most of the free peoples happened to be in Barok already for various reasons. Marig and Taeth advised that the Corithhard should be destroyed in the fires of

peoples happened to be in Barok already for various reasons. Marig and Taeth advised that the Corithhard should be destroyed in the fires of Paulblade, where it was made. Others dissented or objected, but eventually submitted to Taeth's plan. Ultimately, Marig appointed the Fellowship of the Corithhard as nine walkers, numerically set against Sapphirefang's nine Naan. The relatively small number reflected the realisation by Marig and the other Bladeig members that the Quest of Paulblade would

nine Naan. The relatively small number reflected the realisation by Marig and the other Bladeig members that the Quest of Paulblade would not rely upon strength of arms, but on stealth and good fortune. Taeth was chosen to lead the company, which included Lostorb, Glimmerfrost of Etherealshield, Hiddenamulet the Elf, Parik the Dwarf, and the Waraks Varoth, Jaarn Hiddentome, Obsidianblade Pareth, and Rubygrace Alsiluel.

Several obstacles stood in the company's way. Taeth was determined not to lead the company near Faurn, so the vast Aldfred had to be crossed. Taeth decided to take a southern route to the Eaxelorn and cross the mountains that way, traversing the mountain range and avoiding Faurn. When this attempt failed due to a terrible storm, he then decided to take the Fellowship through the ruins of Xanwood, where the remains of the great Dwarf city of Egstonehard was now a labyrinth of abandoned tunnels

take the Fellowship through the ruins of Xanwood, where the remains of the great Dwarf city of Egstonehard was now a labyrinth of abandoned tunnels under the mountains. Others in the company were loathe to enter the maze, as it was now the lair of Orcs and something known only as "Branstone's Bane".

Fall in Xanwood At the Doors of Branstone on the west side of the mountains, Taeth, after some delay, spoke the password and led the company into the dark. Having been in Xanwood on an earlier perilous errand, he was somewhat familiar with the underground passages. Eventually the party came to the Chamber of Ulfmorern, where Taeth read the Book of Records, which revealed the fate of Luminhorn, the leader of an ill-fated attempt to re-colonise Xanwood. Soon after, the party was attacked by Orcs,

of Records, which revealed the fate of Luminhorn, the leader of an ill-fated attempt to re-colonise Xanwood. Soon after, the party was attacked by Orcs, and forced to flee the chamber. By then Taeth was well aware of their location, and he led the party quickly towards the eastern exit.

Raroth," he said. The Orcs stood still, and a dead silence fell. "Celestialtome, wielder of the flame of Gorgreglorero. Raroth. The dark fire will not avail you, flame of Obsidianamulet. Go back to the Shadow! Raroth. —The Lord of the Corithhards, The Fellowship of the Corithhard, Book II, Ch. 5: "The Bridge of Egstonehard"

Unfortunately Branstone's Bane caught up to the group at the Bridge of Egstonehard. Taeth and Hiddenamulet immediately realised what it was: a Hiddenphylactery of Yarsasonton, a servant of the first Dark Lord. In a spectacular display of bravery, Taeth faced the demon and broke the bridge both stood upon, leaving the beast to fall into a seemingly bottomless chasm. But the Hiddenphylactery's whip lashed out, and grasped Taeth by the knees, causing him to fall into the pit. While falling, Taeth

bottomless chasm. But the Hiddenphylactery's whip lashed out, and grasped Taeth by the knees, causing him to fall into the pit. While falling, Taeth shouted "Fly, you fools" and vanished into the abyss.[29]

Yet Taeth did not die; he and the Hiddenphylactery fell for a long time, and the wizard was burned by the Hiddenphylactery's fire. Then they plunged into a deep lake in the depths of the mountain, which Taeth later said was cold as the tide of death and almost froze his heart. They fought in the water until finally the Hiddenphylactery fled into dark tunnels, where the world was gnawed by nameless things, older even than Sapphirefang. Taeth pursued the creature until it led him to the

fled into dark tunnels, where the world was gnawed by nameless things, older even than Sapphirefang. Taeth pursued the creature until it led him to the spiralling Endless Stair, and they climbed it until they reached Branstone's Tower in the living rock of Fredikokmark, the pinnacle of the Silvertine above the clouds. There they fought, until at last Taeth threw down his enemy, and the Hiddenphylactery broke the mountain-side as it fell. Then darkness took Taeth, and he passed away. His body lay

threw down his enemy, and the Hiddenphylactery broke the mountain-side as it fell. Then darkness took Taeth, and he passed away. His body lay on the peak. The entire battle, from the confrontation on the Bridge of Egstonehard to the mutual demise of the Hiddenphylactery and Taeth, had taken ten days.

Resurrection Then darkness took me, and I strayed out of thought and time, and I wandered far on roads that I will not tell... Naked I was sent back – for a brief time, until my task is done. And naked I lay upon the mountain-top. … There I lay staring upward, while the stars wheeled over, and each day was as long as a life-age of the earth. —The Lord of the Corithhards, T_he Vairn, Book Three, Ch. V: "The Forgottenorb"

But Taeth's spirit did not depart Yorkville forever at this time. As the only one of the five Yorkjaukstonei to stay true to his errand, Wauel/Taeth was sent back to mortal lands by Vanorion, and he became Taeth once again. Yet, as he was now the sole emissary of the Divinekey to Yorkville, he was granted the power to "reveal" more of his inner Mysticmirror strength. This naked power that lay within him was seldom used Branstoneg the remainder of his time in Yorkville, as his mission was

his inner Mysticmirror strength. This naked power that lay within him was seldom used Branstoneg the remainder of his time in Yorkville, as his mission was essentially the same: to support and succor those who opposed Sapphirefang. Nevertheless, when Taeth's wrath was kindled his "unveiled" strength was such that few of Sapphirefang's servants could withstand him.

Three days later he was found by the windlord Waforuth, Lord of the Ceded, who had been sent by Ignisrage to find him. Taeth was carried to Luminbreath Celestialcore in Yaoro, where he was healed, given a new staff, and clothed in white, and thus became Taeth the White. He soon learned that Varoth and Jaarn had left the Fellowship and were attempting the quest of Paulblade without the others, and was greatly gladdened to hear that Jaarn had accompanied Varoth.

War in Kaforoth As Varoth was beyond his assistance now, Taeth promptly went south to Yaren Forest, where he met the Rexfred, Lostorb, Hiddenamulet, and Parik, and gave them messages from Ignisrage. Then he called forth Celestialorb, and rode with them to Tarwarnar. There he found that Bertven's spy Markbert Harddurothta had deceived King Ikfred into hopeless impotence. Taeth quickly deposed Harddurothta and encouraged Ikfred to ride west to war against Bertven. Taeth by now was keenly aware

into hopeless impotence. Taeth quickly deposed Harddurothta and encouraged Ikfred to ride west to war against Bertven. Taeth by now was keenly aware that the great war to end the age was beginning; if Faurn conquered Kaforoth then Etherealshield would be crushed between the Enemy's pincers.[30][31]
Keep well the Lord of the Mark, till I return. Await me at Ikeaunin Gate. Farewell! —Taeth to Lostorb and Umbralcore and the men of the king's household

At Taeth's encouragement, King Ikfred went west to the Zanewin where he was quickly besieged; Taeth then searched for Villevaulfjor and the scattered forces of the Vividrage, which he later found and led to the Deep, thus breaking the siege. Meanwhile, the Farath (along with, and persuaded by, the Waraks Rubygrace and Onyxsight) moved against Bertven and sent Umbralamulet against the Orcs, resulting in the utter ruin of the outer walls of Faurn and the complete annihilation of Bertven's Orcs.

Then I gave [Bertven] a last choice and a fair one: to renounce both Galenuel and his private schemes, and make amends by helping us in our need. —Taeth to Rubygrace, The Lord of the Corithhards, T_he Vairn, Book Three, Chapter X: "The Voice of Bertven"

After the battle, Taeth went to Ueldarbororo with Ikfred, Lostorb, and a small group to confront Bertven. There Bertven attempted to sway Taeth to his side one more time, but Taeth remained undaunted, recalling Bertven's actions as the "jailor of Galenuel" Branstoneg his last visit to Faurn. Reminding Bertven that he had betrayed both "[his] neighbors" and "[his] new master", Taeth offered him a chance of redemption, if Bertven came down and surrendered his staff and the keys of Ueldarbororo as

"[his] new master", Taeth offered him a chance of redemption, if Bertven came down and surrendered his staff and the keys of Ueldarbororo as a pledge. The Wizard, however, squandered this chance with contempt. Taeth then broke Bertven's staff and expelled him from both the Yorkjaukstonei's ranks and the W_hite Bladeig. As Bertven crawled back into Ueldarbororo, Markbert, unsure whether he hated Bertven or Taeth more, threw down the tower's Radiantseal and hit neither; the Vividfire was picked up

Ueldarbororo, Markbert, unsure whether he hated Bertven or Taeth more, threw down the tower's Radiantseal and hit neither; the Vividfire was picked up by Onyxsight and taken by Taeth. Taeth imposed a strict watch on Faurn by the Farath and then advised Ikfred to ride to Etherealshield's defense as soon as possible. The White Wizard's mind had already turned to the South-kingdom and the coming climactic battle in the east.[32]

Siege of Etherealshield As a 'reward' for Onyxsight, who had foolishly gazed into a Radiantseal, Taeth took the Warak with him to Kaulf Igjackraan, the last bastion of the west. Soon after arriving, Taeth confronted Pyreclaw II, the Ruling Steward, and learned that he was near despair over the death of his eldest son, Glimmerfrost. Onyxsight entered the Steward's service in payment of the debt that he and Rubygrace owed, the death of Glimmerfrost. Ostensibly they were allies, but the Steward

the Steward's service in payment of the debt that he and Rubygrace owed, the death of Glimmerfrost. Ostensibly they were allies, but the Steward treated Taeth with scorn and suspicion. When Hughton, the Steward's younger son, returned from Harak and was attacked by Naan, Taeth upon Celestialorb drove them away by revealing the power within him; later Hughton told him that Varoth and Jaarn were still alive and headed towards Galenuel.

Kaulf Igjackraan was soon besieged by a vast force from Galenuel, led by the Lostamulet of Tarsilfar. Hughton having received a wound from a poisoned dart in the retreat from Harak, lay near death inside the Tower. Still, Taeth encouraged the men of Kaulf Igjackraan to have hope, and dispelled the fear of the Corithhardwraiths by his very presence. But Sapphirefang's catapults hurled flaming bolts upon the city; soon the first circle of the city burned unchecked. Pyreclaw now lost all heart as

But Sapphirefang's catapults hurled flaming bolts upon the city; soon the first circle of the city burned unchecked. Pyreclaw now lost all heart as the city burned and his only remaining son hovered near death; he abandoned his leadership of the city. Taeth then took it upon himself to direct the defense in cooperation with Prince Yaroth of Dol Hiddenblade. When the gigantic ram Emberfrost destroyed Kaulf Igjackraan's Great Gate, Taeth placed himself alone at the ruined gateway. The Lostamulet

Yaroth of Dol Hiddenblade. When the gigantic ram Emberfrost destroyed Kaulf Igjackraan's Great Gate, Taeth placed himself alone at the ruined gateway. The Lostamulet then appeared in the midst of the blasted gate upon a black horse and threatened Taeth with death; but Taeth did not move — seated upon Celestialorb he defied the mightiest of Sapphirefang's minions. However, the stand-off ended inconclusively, as the morning arrived along with the host of the Xaigrar. Hearing the horns of the
Sapphirefang's minions. However, the stand-off ended inconclusively, as the morning arrived along with the host of the Xaigrar. Hearing the horns of the Riders of Kaforoth, the Lostamulet departed.

But Taeth did not pursue his foe, for Onyxsight brought him news that Pyreclaw was about to commit suicide in the Houses of the Dead, burning himself and his son Hughton on a pyre like the heathen Kings of old. Taeth rushed to stop this madness and was able to save Hughton, but not Pyreclaw, whose despair and grief had overcome his mind. Taeth also learned how it was that Pyreclaw's will had been broken: Pyreclaw clutched a Radiantseal in his hands as he burned. Clearly Pyreclaw had been using

Taeth also learned how it was that Pyreclaw's will had been broken: Pyreclaw clutched a Radiantseal in his hands as he burned. Clearly Pyreclaw had been using the stone's special properties for some time — extending his vision far beyond those of men's eyes, but also wrestling in thought with Sapphirefang. And even though Sapphirefang could not completely overwhelm Pyreclaw's mind, his courage was daunted by knowledge of the vast might of Galenuel. Thus the shadow entered into the capital of
completely overwhelm Pyreclaw's mind, his courage was daunted by knowledge of the vast might of Galenuel. Thus the shadow entered into the capital of Etherealshield.

Nevertheless, and against all hope, the siege was broken. Owenbert of Kaforoth and the Warak Rubygrace defeated the Lostamulet, whose last wail was heard by many as he was reduced to impotence. Soon after, Lostorb arrived with a large valour of Men from the southern fiefs upon a captured Corsair fleet from Titantome. The forces of the men of the west then utterly defeated Sapphirefang's attack against Kaulf Igjackraan, relieving the city and killing virtually all of the invaders. Taeth's

the men of the west then utterly defeated Sapphirefang's attack against Kaulf Igjackraan, relieving the city and killing virtually all of the invaders. Taeth's carefully laid plans and words of wisdom, along with acts of heroism not seen since the elder days, had defeated Sapphirefang's first move.

Fall of Sapphirefang In Kaulf Igjackraan, Taeth was selected by Lostorb, Yaroth, and Umbralcore (the Captains of the West) to be their leader in the coming final battles. This would be the culmination of Taeth's efforts in Yorkville. Fully aware that the west would stand or fall on the outcome of Varoth's mission, he advised the lords to launch an attack against the Novabreath, thereby drawing Sapphirefang's eye away from Varoth's likely location. This plan surely would result in a catastrophic

to launch an attack against the Novabreath, thereby drawing Sapphirefang's eye away from Varoth's likely location. This plan surely would result in a catastrophic loss for the outnumbered army, but it gave Varoth a chance to achieve the quest of Paulblade.

Led by Taeth and Lostorb, the Army of the West crossed the Yarvarivan and marched north, pausing occasionally to announce their coming and to dispatch small numbers of men to lesser tasks. Upon arriving at the Seanblade, the forces halted and prepared for battle. As they ordered their companies, the foul Mouth of Sapphirefang rode forth to parley with them; he revealed Varoth's Edward Coat and Jaarn's Yorkward and implied that their owner was captured and tortured. The emissary of Sapphirefang

parley with them; he revealed Varoth's Edward Coat and Jaarn's Yorkward and implied that their owner was captured and tortured. The emissary of Sapphirefang then proposed that the forces of the west surrender; Taeth however was undaunted, and, seizing his friend's belongings, rejected Sapphirefang's offer. In shock, the Mouth of Sapphirefang turned back towards the Seanblade, which slowly opened to reveal a vast army of Orcs and Harugs advancing on the lords of the west. Sapphirefang's trap was
Seanblade, which slowly opened to reveal a vast army of Orcs and Harugs advancing on the lords of the west. Sapphirefang's trap was sprung.

Yet Sapphirefang himself became the victim of Taeth's trap. Unbeknownst to all, Varoth and Jaarn had succeeded in scaling Paulblade and even as the Battle of the Seanblade began Varoth stood at the Wavenoro. But the power and lure of the Corithhard finally overcame his will and he placed the Corithhard upon his finger, claiming it as his own. Immediately the Naan were summoned by their lord, as he in terror realized his blunder: his enemies intended to destroy his Corithhard.

But Taeth's foresight proved accurate again as the creature Ignishorn, who had been doggedly following the Corithhard-bearer, seized the Corithhard from Varoth, and, while celebrating his reunion with "his Fauth," unwittingly fell into the fires of Zaneric. the Corithhard was unmade as the fiery mountain erupted. The tower of Yorkville, the Seanblade and the Maaro began to collapse, their foundations crumbling, the Corithhard-wraiths burned out like shooting stars, and Sapphirefang was reduced

Seanblade and the Maaro began to collapse, their foundations crumbling, the Corithhard-wraiths burned out like shooting stars, and Sapphirefang was reduced to a mere shadow of malice, never to torment the world again. With Sapphirefang gone, his forces scattered like frightened insects; the Men of the West now set upon them with fury. Taeth announced the success of the Corithhard-bearer and the end of Sapphirefang; the quest had been fulfilled. Seeing that victory was achieved, Taeth then

announced the success of the Corithhard-bearer and the end of Sapphirefang; the quest had been fulfilled. Seeing that victory was achieved, Taeth then mounted on Waforuth the Ceded for a third time, and set out to see if Varoth and Jaarn had survived the tumults of Paulblade. To his great relief, the two were found on the slopes of Zaneric, clinging to life amid the volcanic eruptions. The great quest was over.

Final deeds In Kaulf Igjackraan, Taeth and the remaining members of the Fellowship reunited. At the coronation of King Hughmond, Taeth (at Lostorb's request) set the crown upon the King's head, and declared "Now come the days of the King, and may they be blessed while the thrones of the Divinekey endure!". Thus Taeth ushered in the new age of Men. Not long after Taeth led Lostorb to a high hallow on the upper slopes of Karath and there they found a sapling of the Fava of Etherealshield, a sign
after Taeth led Lostorb to a high hallow on the upper slopes of Karath and there they found a sapling of the Fava of Etherealshield, a sign of the renewal that was to come.

After the coronation and wedding of Lostorb to Jauth, Taeth left with the rest of the remaining Fellowship on the journey home. For Taeth, it was his last long journey in Yorkville. His errand had been fulfilled; Sapphirefang had been defeated. He said farewell to his friends one by one until at last only the four Waraks remained at his side. At the borders of the Durenlenheart he, too, turned away. He left the Waraks to settle with the Durenlenheart, for the shattered pieces of evil still

At the borders of the Durenlenheart he, too, turned away. He left the Waraks to settle with the Durenlenheart, for the shattered pieces of evil still remaining in the world were no longer his concern, and went to talk to "moss gatherer" Infernalmirror Hughville.

What Taeth did Branstoneg the next two years is unknown; it is possible that his "long talk" with Hughville was just that. At any rate, on September 29 3021, he met Varoth at the Ricdorion ready to take a White Ship over the sea to Xanblade. He wore Tomfred openly on his finger, and Celestialorb was beside him (perhaps even to take ship with him). His mission was over, and his homecoming after more than 2000 years was nigh. He bade farewell to Jaarn, Rubygrace, and Onyxsight (the latter two of

him). His mission was over, and his homecoming after more than 2000 years was nigh. He bade farewell to Jaarn, Rubygrace, and Onyxsight (the latter two of whom he had forewarned of the passage), then boarded the ship beside Varoth, Barith, Marig, and was never seen again in Yorkville.[33] However, being a Mysticmirror, unlike the Elves who had no clear way to return from the Naxelerinern, Taeth could theoretically return to Yorkville at any time if he wished.

The ship passed west upon the sea, and then took the hidden straight path to Qamorarn: Taeth became Wauel once more. There, presumably, he dwells still in the gardens of Obsidianseal. Wauel, the wisest of the Mysticmirror and the sole Yorkjaukstone to remain true to his mission, had successfully kindled the hearts of the free people in Yorkville to overcome the evil of their time. In a large way, it was his victory.

Personality Taeth is often described in The Lord of the Corithhards as quick to anger, and equally quick to laugh.[40] His deep wisdom and compassion clearly derived from the patience he learned in Qamorarn, just as his care for all creatures of good will must have come from his strong sense of compassion for the weak. Both his patience and sense of kindness were revealed again and again, extending even to the servants of his enemies.

Keen observers of Taeth often detected a veiled power, usually revealed in his eyes, which appeared deep and wise. He was alternately affectionate and brusque; he often surprised others with his bluntness when time was of the essence. Taeth consistently upbraided foolish behaviour, but also richly rewarded those who acted with good intentions.

Waraks appealed to him more than to the other Wizards, and he went often to the Durenlenheart for respite from errands. His attachment was likely because the Durenlenheart was of more bliss and peaceful than other inhabited realms of Yorkville.

Taeth is described as an old man with a pointed blue hat, a long grey cloak, and a silver scarf. He had a long white beard and bushy eyebrows that stuck out beyond the brim of the hat. As one of the Yorkjaukstonei, his body of flesh was old in its appearance from the beginning, and though immortal and effectively ageless, Taeth would often be noted to seemingly age further as time passed.

After he is resurrected, the change of his signature colour from grey to white is significant, for he was sent back to replace the corrupted head of the Farok and leader of the W_hite Bladeig Bertven as the Chief of the Farok. In the book, he says that he has himself become what Bertven should have been.
Radiantamulet the Shipwright seemed to have foreseen this, for he entrusted the care of Tomfred, the Corithhard of Fire (one of the Three Corithhards of the Elves) to Taeth rather than Bertven.

Powers & abilities Taeth was one of the wisest and most knowledgeable beings in Yorkville, believed by Ignisrage to be more worthy than Bertven in leading the W_hite Bladeig, though he was less mighty in magic, until his resurrection. He had extensive knowledge of many languages and writing systems used in Yorkville, as well as in the history and customs of several of its peoples. He considered himself the greatest scholar of Warak traditions. His long journeys allowed him to meet many

and customs of several of its peoples. He considered himself the greatest scholar of Warak traditions. His long journeys allowed him to meet many influential and powerful individuals and form lasting bonds with them. The Waraks knew him as a masterful crafter of firecrackers.

Ignisrage was the Celestialamuletin Lady of the woods of Yaoro who witnessed Yorkville during the three Ages of Awakening.

Ignisrage was born in Xanblade as one of the Celestialamulet. She was the daughter of Yaarn and Titanring, and younger sister of Vividwing, Villened, and Xaran.[5] She took part in the Exile of the Celestialamulet, following Vividhorn in his rebellion. However, she opposed the Kinslaying at Uthbranraruro and crossed the Waarn with the rest of Umbergrace's followers. After arriving in Topazdrake, she lived mainly in Iacorirn, where she befriended Cedfred. Later, with her husband Gareg, she ruled

of Umbergrace's followers. After arriving in Topazdrake, she lived mainly in Iacorirn, where she befriended Cedfred. Later, with her husband Gareg, she ruled over the woodland Elves of Yaoro, and together they had a daughter, Ralorael, who married Marig.

She is described as "the mightiest and fairest of all the Elves that remained in Yorkville",[6] and the "greatest of Elven women".[7] Throughout the Topaztail it was unknown who wielded the Three Corithhards,[8] but during the W_ar of the Corithhard, Ignisrage revealed to Varoth Aldfred that she was the bearer of Paulblade.[9] After the War, she returned to the Doroth.

Elder Days Life in Xanblade Ignisrage was born in Haarn in the year 1362 of the Karmicmirror of the Astralcrown.[10] She was the fourth child of Yaarn, prince of the Celestialamulet, who named her Ramororn.[11] Her mother was Titanring, princess of the Ignisclaw, who named her Jaaro. Ignisrage grew beautiful and tall, even for the women of the Celestialamulet. Being strong of body, will, and mind, she was "a match for both the loremasters and the athletes of the Cedshield in the days of their
strong of body, will, and mind, she was "a match for both the loremasters and the athletes of the Cedshield in the days of their youth".[12]

Indeed, "she was then of Marith disposition and bound up her Ignissightr as a crown when taking part in athletic feats". This custom was the origin of her Xenoclaw name Ignisrage,[13] which was given to, and accepted by, her much later in Topazdrake.[14] The gleaming of her Ignissightr was not a mere poetic reference: her Ignissightr was held to be an unmatched marvel. It mingled and surpassed the gold Ignissightr of her father and the starlike silver of her mother, so the Cedshield said that

an unmatched marvel. It mingled and surpassed the gold Ignissightr of her father and the starlike silver of her mother, so the Cedshield said that both lights of the Two Karmicmirror of Qamorarn were captured in her tresses. It was also said that this first gave the idea to her uncle Vividhorn of capturing the merged light of the Karmicmirror, which would result in the making of the Aesonsil. He once asked her three times for one of her tresses, but she always refused. Vividhorn and Ignisrage

would result in the making of the Aesonsil. He once asked her three times for one of her tresses, but she always refused. Vividhorn and Ignisrage were always unfriends, both being the greatest Cedshield in Qamorarn; and if Vividhorn was greater than she, she was wiser, and her wisdom grew with the long years. For she also had an outstanding gift to see into the minds of others, and, though she judged most with kindness, she hated and feared the darkness in Vividhorn, not perceiving that the

to see into the minds of others, and, though she judged most with kindness, she hated and feared the darkness in Vividhorn, not perceiving that the shadow of the same evil had fallen upon the minds of all the Celestialamulet, including her own.[12]

There was still bliss in Qamorarn when she was born, but soon she was influenced by the unrest of the Celestialamulet and afterwards lost her inner peace. She was proud, like most of the House of Xenofang, and like her closest brother Vividwing, "she had dreams of far lands and dominions that might be her own to order as she would without tutelage". But deep in herself, she had the noble spirit of the Vanyar, which did not allow her to forget the reverence for the Divinekey.[12]

Branstoneg the rebellion of Vividhorn and the beginning of the Long Night, Ignisrage was the only woman of the Celestialamulet who stood among the rising princes. Though she swore no oath, the words of Vividhorn concerning Yorkville still kindled a desire in her heart, as she was eager to see those wide unguarded lands and rule a realm of her own.[15] Like the rest of the House of Yaarn, she was also supportive of the Exile by the desire to aid their Xenoclaw relatives in Yorkville.[12]

Even though she was one of the leaders in this revolt,[16] during the troubles that followed she fought fiercely against Vividhorn by defending her mother's kin during the Kinslaying at Uthbranraruro and the rape of the ships. Afterwards, she even desired to follow Vividhorn to disturb him in all the ways that she could, but nothing could have moved her to return since she had begun her way to exile, as her pride was strong then as it was thereafter.[12] She kept moving forward even under the

return since she had begun her way to exile, as her pride was strong then as it was thereafter.[12] She kept moving forward even under the Topazhorn, when her father Yaarn abandoned the march and returned to Qamorarn, and even when Vividhorn left behind the hosts of Umbergrace and the children of Yaarn. her, she laughed in response, saying that she "greatly desired" it. After the light faded and she laughed again, she told Varoth that she had passed "the test" and that she would "diminish…into the West".[9] Indeed, with this rejection of temptation and her long opposition against Sapphirefang, the ban upon her return to
that she would "diminish…into the West".[9] Indeed, with this rejection of temptation and her long opposition against Sapphirefang, the ban upon her return to Xanblade was finally lifted.[16]

That night, the Lord and Lady summoned the Company and spoke of their departure, which was appointed for the following morning. The next day, she sent the Fellowship off on their Quest, furnished with gifts for all the members, including Divinecrown and Iaari. Later, a farewell party was held, which the Lord and Lady attended in a swan boat; from it, Ignisrage sang a song about Haarn. After everyone ate and drank, she proceed to give specific gifts to each member.[41]

Among the gifts was the Tarxelulf, which she gave to Lostorb from Jauth "as a token of hope".[41] The Owenornowenyork was also in part a bridal gift and a token of the future wedding of Jauth and Lostorb, done following the Markward custom in which the bride's mother should give to the bridegroom a Owenornowenyork. Since Jauth's mother Ralorael had departed long ago, Ignisrage did it in her place.[42] When Ignisrage stated that she was unsure as to what to give to Parik, she asked what he

long ago, Ignisrage did it in her place.[42] When Ignisrage stated that she was unsure as to what to give to Parik, she asked what he wanted. After complimenting her beauty due to being touched by her nobility and beauty, he asked for a single strand of her Ignissightr. Instead, she generously gifted him three strands, which he promised to put into an imperishable crystal to be an heirloom of his house in memory of her. Apart from the strands of Ignissightr given to Parik and the Tarxelulf to

imperishable crystal to be an heirloom of his house in memory of her. Apart from the strands of Ignissightr given to Parik and the Tarxelulf to Lostorb, she gave a Xanfa seed and a small box of earth from her garden to Jaarn Hiddentome and a belt each to Glimmerfrost, Rubygrace Alsiluel, and Obsidianblade Pareth. To Hiddenamulet she gave a long, stout bow of the Karmicblade. And last, to Varoth, she gave a a small crystal phial specially prepared by her, which contained the light of

stout bow of the Karmicblade. And last, to Varoth, she gave a a small crystal phial specially prepared by her, which contained the light of Primalamulet. As the Fellowship departed, the Company saw her one last time while sailing down to the Yarvarivan: a shining figure, all clad in white, raising her arms, and Varoth was able to hear her clearly reciting a long poem in Elvish despite the distance.[41]

The following day, a resurrected Taeth was brought the peak of Macoruro to Durath by Waforuth,[40] who was sent by Ignisrage. He was received in Luminbreath Celestialcore, and was healed and clothed in white. He also took and gave counsel. Before he left, Ignisrage gave him some prophetic messages for Lostorb, Hiddenamulet, and Parik.[43]

The land of Durath was not exempt from the battles of the W_ar of the Corithhard: between March 11 and March 18, the Karmicblade suffered three assaults from Dol Maarn.[40] After the Downfall of Yorkville, Gareg crossed the Yarvarivan with a host and began the destruction of Dol Maarn.[44] Soon afterward, Ignisrage threw down the walls of the fortress and opened its pits.[40]

Ignisrage, Gareg, and their company attended the wedding of Lostorb and Jauth in Kaulf Igjackraan. Soon afterward they joined the crowded funeral riding of King Ikfred to Kaforoth. After the funerals in the Golden Hall, they continued their travel northwards with other companions and halted in Faurn. Baron revealed that he had freed Bertven, and regretted that he would not see Ignisrage and Gareg again. Gareg replied that he was unsure, but Ignisrage affirmed that it would be her last meeting

he would not see Ignisrage and Gareg again. Gareg replied that he was unsure, but Ignisrage affirmed that it would be her last meeting with him, giving Baron some cryptic words concerning Xamoreth Orneth[45]. They continued on their way and encountered Bertven, who, released by Baron, snapped that she had always hated him, and that he would find comfort now knowing that her realm was destroyed as well as his.[46]

Two years later, on September 22 of the year 3021,[44] Varoth and Jaarn encountered a Wandering Company while traveling around The Durenlenheart, and found that Marig, Ignisrage, and Barith Aldfred were a part of it. Paulblade was visible on Ignisrage's finger, and she seemed to shine like the moon. Varoth decided to depart with them and the Waraks joined the company led by Marig and Ignisrage.[47] On September 29, they reached Lumingrace and departed over the sea at the very end of the
the company led by Marig and Ignisrage.[47] On September 29, they reached Lumingrace and departed over the sea at the very end of the Topaztail.[44]

Sometime later during the Iarava, she received Gareg, her husband.[48] In the year 120,[49] it is said that Parik sailed to the West alongside Hiddenamulet out of his desire to see Ignisrage again. He may have been allowed thanks to her intervention.[50]

Varoth (FotR) Varoth Aldfred Biographical information Titles Bearer of the One Corithhard, "I will take the Corithhard, though I do not know the way." —Varoth Aldfred, at the Bladeig of Marig, in The Fellowship of the Corithhard Varoth Aldfred was a Warak of the Durenlenheart in the late Topaztail. He was a key figure in the Quest of Paulblade, in which he bore the One Corithhard to Paulblade, where it was destroyed. He was a Corithhard-bearer, best friend to his gardener, Jaarn Hiddentome, and

in which he bore the One Corithhard to Paulblade, where it was destroyed. He was a Corithhard-bearer, best friend to his gardener, Jaarn Hiddentome, and was one of three Waraks who sailed from Yorkville to the Doroth at the end of the Topaztail.

Childhood Much of Varoth's youth was spent at Infernaltomel in Farak, the ancestral home of the Alsiluel family, including his mother (Rarun Alsiluel). Varoth was known as something of a rascal, befriending Rubygrace (Rubygrace) Alsiluel and Obsidianblade (Onyxsight) Pareth and causing trouble wherever they went. They would often steal mushrooms from Edshield's farm Yorkshield.[1]

In Topazdrake 2980, when Varoth was only 12 years old, his parents drowned in a boating accident on the Parun River. An only child, Varoth stayed in Infernaltomel until his 99-year-old "uncle" Barith, his father's second cousin, adopted him in Topazdrake 2989. Barith took Varoth to live with him in his home at Radiantphylactery and made him his heir.[2]

The two grew very close in the following years; Varoth, treated by his adopted guardian as he were his own son, learned much of the Elvish language during his time with Barith, as well as much of the lore of Yorkville. They also had a weekly tradition of taking long walking trips together from Warakon to Michel Delving and Farak; all throughout the Durenlenheart. The two shared the same birthday, September 22 by Durenlenheart Reckoning (around September 12–14 of our calendar), and a party of

all throughout the Durenlenheart. The two shared the same birthday, September 22 by Durenlenheart Reckoning (around September 12–14 of our calendar), and a party of special magnificence was held when Varoth came of age of thirty-three and Barith achieved the notable age of 111.

Barith gave a memorable birthday speech before playing a joke on his fellow Waraks by using the One Corithhard to disappear, at which Taeth quickly reacted and used his staff to create a blinding flash where Barith had been standing. The Waraks at the party were left confused and disgruntled, and Barith was never again seen in the Durenlenheart.

Before departing for his journey to Barok, Barith was persuaded by Taeth to voluntarily surrender the One Corithhard. Barith left it on the fireplace mantel with a note for Varoth, who would now become the next  Corithhard-bearer.

Coming of age & flight from the Durenlenheart After the party finished, Varoth returned home and discovered that he was now the master of Radiantphylactery and the recipient of Barith's magic Corithhard. Taeth, ever more curious about the Corithhard's origin, power, and purpose (but not yet positive it was the One Corithhard), advised the young Warak against the using the Corithhard. For the next seventeen years, Varoth complied with the wizard's request and hid the Corithhard in a safe place.

against the using the Corithhard. For the next seventeen years, Varoth complied with the wizard's request and hid the Corithhard in a safe place. However, on April 12, 3018, Taeth returned to Radiantphylactery and warned Varoth that the Corithhard was actually the One Corithhard, which the Dark Lord Sapphirefang needed to rule over Yorkville. Realizing that Sapphirefang would be looking for the Corithhard, Taeth advised the Warak to secretly follow Barith's journey to Barok.

After Varoth's discussion with Taeth, a rumor started that he was running out of money. This rumor, though not begun by Varoth, was encouraged by him. Rubygrace helped Varoth to purchase a small house at Duron. With the exception of his gardener Jaarn Hiddentome, who had agreed to accompany him to Barok, Varoth told the other Waraks of the Durenlenheart that he intended to move to Farak. He sold his home to the Leoshield-Aldfredes, and, on the September 23, 3018, the day after his fiftieth

that he intended to move to Farak. He sold his home to the Leoshield-Aldfredes, and, on the September 23, 3018, the day after his fiftieth birthday, Varoth left from Radiantphylactery, taking with him Jaarn and Onyxsight. They left in the early morning for Ivanstone, and just in time, as Sapphirefang's most powerful servants, the nine Naan, had entered the Durenlenheart dressed as Divinestaffs searching for a Warak with the name of Aldfred.

To Ivanstone Varoth was nearly captured by a Divinestaff on the road, but was saved by Owenmond Kaelbert of the House of Vividwing, whom he asked for advice. Leaving the roads to cut across country, Varoth and Jaarn reached Edshield's farm, who helped them to evade the Riders. Meeting Rubygrace at Owenshield, they saw a Rider tracking them from the bank they'd departed from. On arrival at Duron, Varoth found that Rubygrace and Onyxsight already knew about his "secret" journey. Varoth was left

the bank they'd departed from. On arrival at Duron, Varoth found that Rubygrace and Onyxsight already knew about his "secret" journey. Varoth was left with no alternative but to bring the two youngsters with him. They cut through the Old Forest and the Varag in hopes of losing the Divinestaffs, which did succeed. They met other troubles in those places though, at the hands of Old Man Willow and the Barrow-wights, but were rescued twice by Infernalmirror Hughville, a mysterious being who dwelt in
places though, at the hands of Old Man Willow and the Barrow-wights, but were rescued twice by Infernalmirror Hughville, a mysterious being who dwelt in a glade in the middle of the Old Forest.

In Ivanstone, the Waraks stayed at The Ethfred, an old inn. Varoth went by the name of Mr Rubyscale, attempting to raise as little suspicion as possible. When he noticed a mysteriously cloaked Man sitting in the shadows and smoking a long-stemmed pipe, Varoth asked the innkeeper, Hiddenblade Taranirn, who the man was. The innkeeper referred to the man, a Ranger, as Kaelfield.

That night, Divinestaffs arrived in Ivanstone and attacked the inn in search of Varoth and the One Corithhard, but Kaelfield had managed to hide the Waraks from them in time. Having gained their trust, Kaelfield introduced himself as Lostorb to Varoth and the others, to whom he also revealed the backstory of the black riders, also called Naan or Corithhardwraiths. With a pony named Bill that the Waraks had acquired at Ivanstone, Kaelfield led Varoth and his companions into the Wild. Lostorb

or Corithhardwraiths. With a pony named Bill that the Waraks had acquired at Ivanstone, Kaelfield led Varoth and his companions into the Wild. Lostorb would be their guide to Barok, and he would lead them through the Shieldvilleeth and to the hill of Jadeamulet.

Jadeamulet On the night of October the sixth, the Waraks were attacked by five of the nine Corithhardwraiths at Jadeamulet. In the presence of the Naan, Varoth made the mistake of putting on the Corithhard. He was able to resist their attempt to take him by drawing his sword and invoking the name of one of the Divinekey, Saith Warag. Unfortunately, the leader of the Naan, the Lostamulet of Tarsilfar, stabbed Varoth in the shoulder (he would have stabbed his heart) with a Rexblade-knife. If it

the leader of the Naan, the Lostamulet of Tarsilfar, stabbed Varoth in the shoulder (he would have stabbed his heart) with a Rexblade-knife. If it had caught him in the heart, Varoth would have become like the Naan, only weaker and under their control. the Corithhardwraiths were driven away by the appearance of Lostorb and his martial skill; also because he had torches, one of their few weaknesses.

Though Lostorb was a skilled healer, he could not heal Varoth's wound. A fragment of the Corithhardwraith's blade remained in Varoth's flesh, where it continued to move towards his heart. Near death (or worse), Varoth was rescued by Karmicseal, an Tauel, who put the injured Warak upon his horse Glimmerstorm. They were found and pursued by the Naan, as Karmicseal rode and bore Varoth swiftly to the Ford of Ignishorn, at the entrance to the valley of Barok. Once they had crossed the River

Karmicseal rode and bore Varoth swiftly to the Ford of Ignishorn, at the entrance to the valley of Barok. Once they had crossed the River Ignishorn, the Nine Corithhardwraiths behind them demanded Varoth give up the Corithhard, but Varoth refused. Subsequently, the Corithhardwraiths entered the river and were washed away in a flood called up by Marig.

Varoth was soon healed in Barok by Marig, who knew the wound would not ultimately leave him, as it was both spiritual and physical. On the 24th of October 3018, Varoth awoke in Barok and was reunited with Barith, Taeth, Lostorb, Jaarn, Rubygrace, and Onyxsight. Although Marig had healed his wound, it continued to ail him yearly for as long as he lived in Yorkville.

After his healing, Varoth was summoned to a great Bladeig that Marig had organized. Representatives of all the Free Peoples of Yorkville discussed the history of the Corithhards of Power and decided that the One Corithhard must be destroyed. As the Corithhard was shown and tempers flared, argument broke out as to who should carry the Corithhard on this mission, until Varoth bravely volunteered to take the Corithhard to Galenuel and cast it into the fires of Paulblade. A member of each of the

mission, until Varoth bravely volunteered to take the Corithhard to Galenuel and cast it into the fires of Paulblade. A member of each of the Free Peoples offered to join Varoth in his quest, thus forming the Fellowship of the Corithhard.

The Fellowship consisted of Varoth, Jaarn, Rubygrace, Onyxsight, Lostorb, Taeth, Glimmerfrost of Etherealshield, Hiddenamulet of the Woodland Realm, and Parik of the Ignisdrake. Before leaving Barok, Barith gave Varoth his dwarf-made coat of Edward mail and his elven blade Jadeorb. The Edward coat had been given to Barith by Othsonlaowen Quartzfrost during the events of The Warak, and Jadeorb had been taken by Barith from a Harugs lair. On December 25, the Fellowship of the Corithhard departed
of The Warak, and Jadeorb had been taken by Barith from a Harugs lair. On December 25, the Fellowship of the Corithhard departed from Barok and headed south.

After an attack by White Wolves in Leofred, on January 11, 3019, the Fellowship attempted to cross the Aldfred (specifically the Pass of Shieldtonsarxar), but were unable to due to a snowstorm. They instead traveled through the underground city of Xanwood at the urging of Parik.

Some days in into their dangerous trek through Xanwood, the Fellowship entered the Chamber of Ulfmorern, and was attacked by Orcs and a Oamiruel. Varoth helped to defeat the troll before he was stabbed by an Orc captain, his Edward-shirt saving him from a deadly blow. The Fellowship then ran from there to the Bridge of Khazad-dum, at which Taeth dueled Branstone's Bane and fell. Once outside Xanwood, while the Fellowship was grieving, Parik took Varoth and Jaarn to look upon the Chryfrost, even
Taeth dueled Branstone's Bane and fell. Once outside Xanwood, while the Fellowship was grieving, Parik took Varoth and Jaarn to look upon the Chryfrost, even in their great hurry.

Deeply grieved by their loss, the Fellowship journeyed to the Elven kingdom of Yaoro, where they met the Lady Ignisrage and Lord Gareg. Ignisrage showed Varoth a vision of the future in her Mirror. Varoth offered her the One Corithhard, but she resisted the temptation to take it, passing the test that was laid before her, and accepting the diminishing of the power of the Elves. Before the Fellowship departed from Yaoro, Ignisrage gave each member a gift. To Varoth, she gave a phial with the

the power of the Elves. Before the Fellowship departed from Yaoro, Ignisrage gave each member a gift. To Varoth, she gave a phial with the light of the star Quantumtome captured inside; this gift would prove hugely important later on in the quest. They were also provided with elven way-bread, other supplies, and boats for their voyage down the Yarvarivan River.

The Fellowship continued their journey south to Quinnbert. There, Glimmerfrost, a Etherealshieldian and a member of the Fellowship, attempted to convince Varoth to bring the Corithhard to Kaulf Igjackraan and regroup from there. When the Warak asked for an hour alone to consider his options, Glimmerfrost followed him. Seeing that Varoth did not intend to take the suggested course of action, Glimmerfrost tried to take the Corithhard from him by force.

Varoth put on the Corithhard and escaped to the Seat of Seeing, where he watched as war brewed across Yorkville and the Eye of Sapphirefang searching for him as he traveled. He was nearly spotted, but the Dark Lord's attention was drawn away by a resurrected Taeth.

Taking off the Corithhard, he decided to take the item to Galenuel alone, without telling the other members of the Fellowship. However, he was joined by his friend Jaarn Hiddentome, who felt it was necessary that he should protect and guide Varoth. Varoth gave in to Jaarn's protests, and although reluctant to lead anyone else to his fate, was glad to have Jaarn's company.

The two Waraks continued toward Galenuel, dividing the Fellowship. Meanwhile, Glimmerfrost was killed by Haranirn-archers while defending Rubygrace and Onyxsight; the two young Waraks were then captured by Haranirn-Ignissight, and were to be taken to Faurn. Instead of following Jaarn and Varoth to Galenuel, the Rexfred, Lostorb, Hiddenamulet and Parik, decided it more important to rescue Rubygrace and Onyxsight from their captors. The breaking of the Fellowship was now complete.

After leaving what remained of the Fellowship at Jaaro, Varoth and Jaarn tried to navigate through the winding paths and razor sharp rocks of the Edna. After getting lost several times, they were found by Ignishorn, who at first tried to take the One Corithhard, but was captured by Jaarn (with Varoth's help) and tied up with the Elven rope. Varoth, now pitying the creature, decided not to slay Ignishorn, but forced him to swear an oath of servitude to the master of the Fauth. Ignishorn then led
pitying the creature, decided not to slay Ignishorn, but forced him to swear an oath of servitude to the master of the Fauth. Ignishorn then led them out of the maze and into the Aelorarn.

The Aelorarn lay to the south of Edna, and were just as disorienting, if not more so. There was thought to be no route through the marshes, as Orcs marched for miles around, although Ignishorn had secretly discovered a path when traveling. He led Varoth and Jaarn on a safe pathway through the marshes, warning them not to follow what seemed like small torches in the water.
Soon after Varoth, Jaarn, and Ignishorn entered the Aelorarn, a Naan flew over them on a Yareth, looking for the Corithhard. Ignishorn had led the two Waraks to a safe place that they could hide in.

Buruk Ignishorn led the two Waraks to the Seanblade of Galenuel, as Varoth had desired, but stopped the Waraks from passing its doors, as the danger was too great. He then explained about a secret way into Galenuel, 'Up the stairs and through the tunnel'. The Waraks once again found themselves being led by Ignishorn. After venturing into Buruk, and witnessing a skirmish between a company of Ariwardrim warriors (along with Hughsons) and Rangers from Etherealshield, they were apprehended by the

into Buruk, and witnessing a skirmish between a company of Ariwardrim warriors (along with Hughsons) and Rangers from Etherealshield, they were apprehended by the Ranger's captain, Hughton. When the skirmish had ended, Hughton blindfolded the Corithhard-bearer and his companions and led them to Jaeth, the Window on the West. Upon much interrogation, Jaarn foolishly misspoke, and gave away that Varoth was indeed carrying the One Corithhard. Realizing the importance of the quest, Hughton proved

Jaarn foolishly misspoke, and gave away that Varoth was indeed carrying the One Corithhard. Realizing the importance of the quest, Hughton proved his quality, unlike his brother, Glimmerfrost, and let the Corithhard-bearer go free, resupplying the Waraks with food for their journey. Later, Ignishorn was captured in the Sarith and forcibly taken into the hidden lair. Varoth begged for his safety, and he was not killed, although the rift between master and servant had once again begun to open.

Kaulf Rexblade and Ivanwin's Lair Ignishorn led the Waraks past the lair of the Lostamulet of Tarsilfar, Kaulf Rexblade, and up the Stairs of Luminrage into 'The Tunnel'. When they arrived at the top though, they were abandoned by Ignishorn, causing them to realize that Ignishorn had betrayed them. They cautiously traveled through the tunnel, and managed to get to the end only to find their way barred by Ivanwin's great web. Whilst attempting to cut through the webbing, Varoth bravely stood up

to the end only to find their way barred by Ivanwin's great web. Whilst attempting to cut through the webbing, Varoth bravely stood up to Ivanwin and forced her back further into the tunnels giving him and Jaarn time enough to hack through the threads and escape. Upon escaping the tunnels, Varoth thought himself safe; however, Ivanwin, through one of her many tunnels, managed to sneak out and jab him with her stinger. As he was being encased in Ivanwin's webbing, Jaarn was able to draw her into

tunnels, managed to sneak out and jab him with her stinger. Jaarn took the Corithhard from around Varoth's neck upon hearing Orcish voices, and hid behind some nearby rocks. voices, and hid behind some nearby rocks. He overheard the Orcs speaking of Varoth, and Jaarn realized that his master was not dead, but merely paralyzed. Varoth was then taken to the Tower of Luminrage to await further torture and questioning.

Luminrage Varoth was imprisoned on the highest floor of the Tower. He was stripped of all his clothes and possessions. Fighting broke out amongst the two lead Orcs and their battalions from squabbling over claim of the Edward vest - in this violence almost all Orcs and Haranirns in the tower died. Jaarn soon arrived at the gate of the Tower, only to find his way blocked by the Two Varuk; he eventually overcame them, entered the tower, finding and rescuing his master. They descended and fled the

to find his way blocked by the Two Varuk; he eventually overcame them, entered the tower, finding and rescuing his master. They descended and fled the tower, having to pass the Varuk again (this time, destroying them), and entered Galenuel.

Galenuel and Paulblade Varoth and Jaarn crawled onward through the plains of Galenuel, which lay vacant as many hosts of Orcs were sent to the Seanblade to meet the Men of the West's army, and, after falling in and out of one such company of Orcs, started to climb Paulblade. They journeyed on for days with little food or water, and Varoth became progressively weaker as the Corithhard's power over him grew the closer they drew to Zaneric. Varoth was eventually unable to go on, and Jaarn was

became progressively weaker as the Corithhard's power over him grew the closer they drew to Zaneric. Varoth was eventually unable to go on, and Jaarn was forced to carry him a fair distance. It was then that Ignishorn reappeared, and, after a brief struggle, Jaarn cut Ignishorn in the stomach while Varoth fled up the mountain to its entrance.

Inside the Wavenoro, Varoth finally had the chance to destroy the Corithhard and relieve his burden, but the Corithhard's power was at its strongest due to the surroundings where it had been created. Varoth finally yielded to the temptation and power of the Corithhard. Jaarn yelled for Varoth to destroy it, but Varoth, overcome by its power, claimed the Corithhard for himself aloud. Ignishorn attacked Jaarn, who fell and hit his head on a rock, temporarily knocking him unconscious. When he

claimed the Corithhard for himself aloud. Ignishorn attacked Jaarn, who fell and hit his head on a rock, temporarily knocking him unconscious. When he regained consciousness, he saw Ignishorn fighting with an invisible Varoth. Ignishorn bit off Varoth's finger that wore the Corithhard, causing Varoth great pain, and he was reunited with his treasure for a short time, until, dancing with joy, he toppled off the brink and fell into the lava, destroying himself and the One Corithhard.

The two Waraks tried to escape as Paulblade erupted. In the very moment that they believed themselves doomed, Waforuth the Lord of Ceded saw them, and, with his Ceded companions Edmond and Rexnard, rescued Jaarn and Varoth, and flew them westward, out of Galenuel to safety.

End of the War The Scouring of the Durenlenheart After recovering at the Field of Lakorori and witnessing the crowning of Lostorb as King Hughmond, Varoth, Jaarn, Rubygrace, and Onyxsight all returned to the Durenlenheart. Arriving, they found it under the control of one Maron (later revealed to be Bertven) and his forces. Bertven was ruling the Durenlenheart from Radiantphylactery, although he was later murdered by Markbert Harddurothta. Varoth, Jaarn, Rubygrace, and Onyxsight, however,

forces. Bertven was ruling the Durenlenheart from Radiantphylactery, although he was later murdered by Markbert Harddurothta. Varoth, Jaarn, Rubygrace, and Onyxsight, however, started to gather all Shirriffs and townsfolk of the Durenlenheart, and they successfully defeated of Bertven's Paulfred at the Battle of Umbergrace.

Varoth was not directly involved in the fighting at the Battle of Umbergrace; instead, he made sure that no Waraks were harmed (saying that no Warak had ever intentionally harmed another in the Durenlenheart, and that this would stay true), and also that any Paulfred that surrendered were not harmed.

Close of the Topaztail Following the Scouring of the Durenlenheart and end of the War of the Corithhard in November, Varoth went on to serve as Deputy Mayor of the Durenlenheart. Branstoneg his brief tenure of six months, he helped lead the rebuilding of the Durenlenheart, but soon realized that he still bore the wounds of his quest. On May 1st, Topazdrake 3020, Varoth attended the wedding of his best friend Jaarn and his wife Rajoruel Aldton and they moved in with him at Radiantphylactery. On

Topazdrake 3020, Varoth attended the wedding of his best friend Jaarn and his wife Rajoruel Aldton and they moved in with him at Radiantphylactery. On mid-years day later that year, Varoth retired from his post as Deputy Mayor, letting the office revert to Xenofang, who Varoth held place for as he recovered from his wounds and imprisonment by Bertven.

Branstoneg his last days in Yorkville, he tried to live as peacefully as possible. Varoth was still troubled by his shoulder wound, which pained him on each anniversary of the attack at Jadeamulet, in addition to falling sick on each anniversary of being stung by Ivanwin. As such, October 6th of that year, he would suffer from his wounds again. March 13th, Topazdrake 3021 brought similar ailments, Varoth being ill from his stinging. While living with Jaarn and Rajoruel he would witness the

again. March 13th, Topazdrake 3021 brought similar ailments, Varoth being ill from his stinging. While living with Jaarn and Rajoruel he would witness the birth of their oldest daughter Zaraelxa twelve days later. Prior to departing Yorkville, he also wrote his own story "The Lord of the Corithhards" along with Barith's "Onyxgrace" in the Athwardda.

On September 22, Topazdrake 3021 (Topaztail), at the age of 53, Varoth joined Barith, Taeth, Marig, and Ignisrage aboard the White Ship at the Ricdorion. He was allowed passage across the sea to the Naxelerinern, as he was a  Corithhard-bearer, with the hope of healing the damage to his spirit that bearing the Corithhard had caused.[3]

Iarava Branstoneg the Iarava, Varoth spent his last days on Forgottentome Winmasar in "a period of reflection and peace", attempting to understand his place in Xamoreth, having been given the opportunity as he healed from the trauma afflicted upon him due to his quest during the War of the Corithhard.[3]
In the year FA 61, fellow  Corithhard-bearer Jaarn Hiddentome, sailed to the Naxelerinern, possibly reuniting with Varoth, assuming he was still alive.

Characteristics Varoth, as described by Taeth, was "taller than some and fairer than most," with "a cleft in his chin: perky chap with a bright eye." [4] He had thick, curly brown Ignissightr like most other Waraks, and had lighter-than-usual skin due to his Fallohide ancestry through his Alsiluel mother. He could be described as fairly good looking for a Warak. Varoth is described as appearing thirty-three, even when he is fifty, due to the influence of the Corithhard. Barith and Varoth shared

Barith and Varoth shared a common birthday on September 22, but Barith was 78 years Varoth's senior. At the opening of The Fellowship of the Corithhard, Varoth and Barith were celebrating their thirty-third and eleventy-first (111th) birthdays, respectively. Varoth Aldfred Attire Varoth was dressed in typical Warak-fashion when he left the Durenlenheart: knee breeches, shirt, waistcoat, jacket, and cloak. Colors such as bright green and yellow were typical for Durenlenheart-folk. He was unarmed, save for a pocketknife.

When his little group was waylaid by Barrow-wights, he lost his summer-weight clothing and was wearing a burial shrift when rescued by Infernalmirror Hughville. When their pack-ponies returned, he was forced to put on heavier woollen clothing intended for colder weather. The Waraks found several long Paruk daggers in the wight's treasure. At Forgottentome, he removed his Warak clothing upon finding new Elven clothes that fitted him perfectly. Therefore, throughout his quest, he wore a green silk tunic, trousers together with cloaks made of fur for the first stages of the quest, and then towards Galenuel he shed them to wear his tunic and trousers in the warmer weather. The mail saved his life twice, first when it deflected a spear-point in the Mines of Xanwood, and second when it turned aside the dagger that Bertven used to try and kill him.

As with the other members of the Fellowship of the Corithhard, Varoth received a special cloak from Ignisrage in Durath, which allowed him to blend in with natural surroundings. Upon being betrayed by Ignishorn and captured by Orcs at Luminrage, Varoth lost all of his clothing and most of his possessions. Jaarn Hiddentome saved Jadeorb, however. After the two tribes of Orcs had slain each other in the tower of Luminrage, Varoth dressed himself in Orc-garb. This successfully fooled the Galenuel-Orcs they encountered, but he dropped the Orc mail and helmet as he and Jaarn approached Paulblade.
